story:
Short Summary

As our local farms have disappeared over the last several decades, it has left a huge hole in our communities. The mission of Keelboat Farms is to fill that void by building a community-focused, learning-centered farm committed to bringing people together and inspiring the next generation of farmers.

Our Farm's Impact

Our goal is to grow enough vegetables to distribute 300 crates to our community during the upcoming growing season. For each contribution of $25, we will deliver a crate of vegetables to a local family. 


Our Farm's Objectives:

Learning at Keelboat Farms

  • Our programs are based on what we call "Free-Range Learning". We believe that learning is an exploratory process that can happen anywhere and anytime. Our programs are designed to make learning authentic, hands-on, meaningful, and fun.
  • Our learning experiences are built on our Build Knowledge, Build Community, Build a Farm concept. Learners become active participants in building the farm and our community, while building new knowledge that they can take back into their own communities.
  • A sample program might look something like this: a community group (like a Brownie troop or baseball team) spends part of the morning harvesting and packing tomatoes for our CSA program. Afterwards, we all head to the kitchen for a class on making homemade salsa. Each student goes home with a jar of salsa and a new experience that can help them make an impact in their own community.

Our CSA Program

  • Our CSA program is just an extension of our Build Knowledge, Build Community, Build a Farm concept. Our goal is to show how sustainable farming and eating local can solve many of the problems related to our current global food system. We hope to make an impact on the health of our community by connecting people to real food grown without chemicals or synthetic pesticides. 
  • Our CSA program is a unique model that blends the subscription membership found in most traditional CSAs with a donation-based system that allows us to reach more of our community.
  • Donated CSA shares are distributed through our Nominate-a-Crate program. This program lets people in the community help decide who our extra crates of vegetables will go to. It could be a family in need, a local hero who deserves a pat on the back, or just someone who could use a little pick-me-up.
Sustainability & Restoration Efforts

  • All of our crops are grown using sustainable agricultural practices, such as planting a diverse mix of crops, composting to build soil fertility, and using an integrated pest management approach.
  • Our sustainability efforts extend beyond the farmed areas of our property. We plan to protect/restore our farm's ecosystem by preserving natural spaces, replacing invasive species with native plants, and creating wildlife habitat.
  • By restoring and protecting our farm ecosystem, we're creating a vibrant, and dynamic, natural classroom that allows us to increase our understanding of the world around us.


What the Funding Will Be Used For

To ensure that we are able to provide a quality product to our community and meet our 300 crate commitment, we need to purchase the following:

  • Drip irrigation and water storage - sufficient watering aids plant growth and makes crops less susceptible to disease
  • Seed starting supplies - we've been starting our own seeds for many years, but need to scale up our operation to meet the demands of a community farm
  • Tools and implements - since most of the work will be done by hand, it is important to have quality tools to do the job efficiently
  • Cold storage - harvested crops must be stored in a controlled environment prior to delivery to protect quality, flavor & nutritional value
  • Packaging and delivery supplies - includes delivery crates and setting up a prep/packaging area
  • Crop protection - includes solar fencing, pest control netting, and frost protection to extend the growing season

Risks & Challenges
The project scope is scaleable, which helps to minimize much of the risk. If we only receive funding for 200 crates, the associated costs for irrigation, crop protection and other supplies go down proportionately. The program can still be implemented, although the reach and impact will be reduced.


Anytime you take on a new endeavor, especially a project of this magnitude, there are bound to be unforeseen challenges that crop up. We believe the following factors will allow us to overcome these challenges:

  • We have a well-researched and thorough plan that has been developed over a period of several years.
  • We plan to follow sound sustainable agricultural practices to avoid/mitigate some of the traditional risks associated with farming (pest infestations, plant diseases, crop failure, etc.).
  • We have extensive personal experience in the fields of biology, science education, and business, which will help us in various aspects of our project.
  • During the last 10 years, we've planted over 100 varieties of vegetables and experimented with a number of growing techniques to find what works best.
Most importantly, we are not taking on this project alone:
  • We will be partnering with individuals and organizations in our local community who want to help build something meaningful.
  • We have a personal network of new and experienced farmers to share information with and learn from.
  • We have a personal network of amazingly talented and insightful educators who are willing to collaborate with us on our educational initiative.


How You Can Help

Become a contributor and help us reach our 300 crate goal.

Even if you aren't able to contribute to our campaign, there is still plenty you can do.

  • Help us build momentum by getting the word out to your friends and family who might be interested in our project.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools at the top of the page to spread the word about our campaign on your favorite social networks.
  • Check out our website at www.KeelboatFarms.com and share the link with your online community.
  • Become an active member of our Facebook Community. Like our Facebook page to keep up to date on all of our farm happenings and participate in our farm promotions.

story:
Short Summary

Blackhawk Swim and Dive Club is a non-profit organization that has been providing a place for families to spend the hot summers and for the Blackhawk Swim and Dive teams to practice and compete for over 40 years.  It is a place where children build friendships, learn to work as a team, learn to be leaders, learn to compete fairly, and more.

To help provide a safe environment, the floor of the pool needs some minor repairs and completely repainted.  We have a company who has offered to provide the labor to complete these tasks.  We need to raise the funds to cover the cost of the paint.

What we need

We need to raise $3,500 to cover the cost of paint.  It will take 30-35 gallons and 3 to 4 weeks to do it properly.  We only have a short period to get this done.  We need your help to be able to make this happen before opening day.  If we are unable to raise the funds, then we will have to wait and the floor of the pool will continue to decay and become more costly to repair.

The Impact

Your donation will will help this non-profit continue to provide a safe facility for children and their families.  Over the past couple years, there have been some large repair expenses (pump and heater) that have prevented us from being able to make this happen without additional funding.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to help, please spread the word to others who may be able to help.

story:
Short Summary

  • Regardless of who the steering committee has chosen, this was the most innovative, most meaningful, and best entry in the Philips Innovation Fellows / Bloomberg News Next Big Thing competition. 
  • See for yourself at: http://www.indiegogo.com/partners/philips

  • This campaign is closed.  You can still help by visiting me at:

    fundrazr.com/campaigns/7cHe4/ab/61mkb2

  • My name is Robert DeDomenico.  For over three years now, I have been developing a prototype system for the automated utility transport of small payloads, such as a gallon of milk, or a loaf of bread.  At a cost of only $4,500 so far, the major design work, most of the construction of the first vehicle subassembly, and construction of the first section of test track are already complete.  I am a lifelong tinkerer.  I grew up on a farm and began experiencing equipment maintenance and repair from a young age.  I have been a submariner, electronics technician, nuclear operator, and computer scientist, and have actively enjoyed the hobbies of model railroading, bicycling, sailing, windsurfing, hang gliding, scuba diving, and RC cars & helicopters.  
  • My goal is to change the world by revolutionizing the way we transport solid physical objects, to help us live well, stay healthy, and enjoy life.  Winning first place will help me achieve this.
  • I will complete the first demonstration prototype system, and use this demonstrator to win private and government backing for a first real service installation.  I have just submitted an application to the New York State Energy Research Development Authority (NYSERDA), Program Opportunity Notice 2781 Advanced Transportation Concepts.  I will also be submitting an abstract to the US Department of Energy Unsolicited Proposal Program.  Success in this campaign will enhance each of these applications.
  • Implementation of this technology will revolutionize the way we shop for groceries, get prescriptions, send and receive the mail, discard trash… move any small payload in general… down the block, around town or across state.  It will reduce miles driven in America by between 5% and 10%, with a proportional drop in traffic congestion, accident rates, and demand for petroleum fuel.  As containerized freight has done in long haul transport, this technology will will do in "last mile" distribution, reducing handling costs and final prices while improving the availability and variety of goods to us all.

Some background on the problem and solution:  In America, we consume about 100 quadrillion BTU's of energy per year.  (Global consumption is about 500 quads.)  About 40% of this is oil, and about two thirds of that is for transportation.  In addition to moving people, vehicles of course transport materials and goods.  Energy to move materials and goods is typically boiled down to units of BTU's consumed per ton of payload per mile of transport, or BTU per ton-mile.  The most efficient movement of material and goods is by water, rail, and pipeline, all typically on the order of a few hundred BTU/ton-mile.  The US trucking industry moves payloads for a few thousand BTU/ton-mile.  When we move goods with our cars though, we are using a few thousand BTU's per mile whether we are carrying anything or not, and how often are we carrying a ton of goods?  Let's take an example of driving to the local sandwich shop in the morning for some breakfast sandwiches and a gallon of milk.  The milk weighs a whopping 8 pounds, and the sandwiches might add up to another pound, but let's just say two.  The whole payload then is 10 lbs, or 1/200th of a ton.  If the car were a Prius getting 57 mpg, it is still burning 2,000 BTU per mile.  So the payload is moving for 400,000 BTU per ton mile... one way!  (The driver had to make a round trip.)  The CargoFish system will be able to move this same payload for about 20 BTU's per mile.  (That's energy burned at the electric plant, and counting all the losses of conversion to electricity, distribution, and vehicle efficiency.)  Our almost universal assumption that in order to move anything any reasonable distance on an immediate basis requires a car, is actually incorrect.  It requires moving only what matters, and as little else as possible.  Imagine if we all had to transport every gallon of water home as if from the grocery store.  Driving it all wouldn't be a very effective solution, would it?  Please feel free to ask about any concerns you have.  My concern is that it is unsustainable to continue putting thousands of pounds of motorized machinery in motion every time we want to get a few pounds from here to there.  I think we can do better, and I hope you agree because I need your vote to win first place, which will help immensely with getting a faster pace going on developing and implementing this technology.  Thank you very much.  I will not let you down.

What We Need & What You Get

  • In order to prove the technical and fiscal feasibility of this system well enough to warrant investment, people are going to need to see it.  I need to complete the demonstration prototype of about 400 feet of track and at least one vehicle.  The current material cost for track adds up to $6 per foot, totaling $2,400 for this phase.  I also need to progress the first vehicle, whose first wheel set is nearly done, by finishing this assembly, building another identical wheel set, then constructing the main body frame and assembling all three into a completed vehicle.  The motor, controller, wheels, racks, gears, pulleys, belts, bearings, shafts, fasteners, and frame materials for the first wheel set totaled about $1,000.  Another $1,000 will be needed for the second wheel set assembly.  My present estimate for the components and materials necessary to complete the main frame, assemble these three into one vehicle, and install an initial control system is another $600.  With this total of $4,000 for parts and materials, I will be able to complete a system able to demonstrate semi-autonomous control of one vehicle over any emulated arbitrary path.
  • I have a website for the project, where I will post a list of every contributor to this campaign.  Every contributor will be invited to selected project milestone(s), such as first public demonstration.  Other perks include bundle(s) of free service, redeemable when this system becomes available at the contributors'  primary abode, vacation house, or place of business.  (See the specific perks for details.)
  • The first $1,600 of funds raised will go toward completion of the first vehicle.
  • The next $2,400 of funds raised will go toward test track construction.
  • Additional winnings will be used to build 3 additional vehicles.
  • Funds beyond that will be used carefully, in support of the project.

The Impact

This project will raise our standard of living.  This technology is the closest thing to the Star Trek transporter that the world will ever realize.  It will become the Physical Internet, connecting most households in the US.  Even before reaching that level of adoption, early installations in senior living complexes will restore a significant measure of self-sufficiency to many of us as we age, as independent travel by driving or otherwise becomes more inconvenient, difficult, or altogether impossible.  Other early adoption communities will have residents enjoying more free time as they do not find themselves compelled to travel for needs that must be met more immediately than mail order, Fedex, or UPS.  Businesses will exchange documents and/or other physical objects at levels of service exceeding the best and fastest courier companies, at a fraction of the cost.  More workers will be able to telecommute because they will not be limited to exchanging only voice and information over the telephone and Internet.  Because this technology will prove worth installing, an entire industry will grow to install, maintain, and expand it, providing local construction, maintenance, operation and administration jobs wherever it goes.  The reduction in transportation fuel consumption will boost the economy.  In addition to small payloads, all of these benefits can be delivered by this technology.

This will be no more expensive than municipal water or sewer.  Those systems involve miles of underground infrastructure, yet are the most effective and inexpensive way to deliver water and remove waste.  The household bill for those services is low enough that most people have to look it up to tell me how much it costs.  Don't jump to premature conclusions about something "totally not plausible", or too expensive to prove practical.  Infrastructure does cost, but returns enormous value, and, spread out over millions of customers the costs are more affordable than the alternative of doing without.  Please take the time to browse the comments, where I have re-posted several of my favorite correspondences received.

I’ve recently given a presentation to the Rowan University Honors Engineering class of 2016, as well as another to several officials at the New York State Energy Research Development Authority.

Your contribution: financial, comments, or just spreading awareness, will help me accelerate development, build and prove this technology. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t contribute financial support, I could still use your help:

  • Please spread the word. 
  • Like this campaign page, tweet this campaign page, etc.
  • Like my facebook page: CargoFish Physical Internet
  • Offer your comments, or ask any questions. here, or through the contact form on my website: www.cargofish.com.
  • Compare my campaign to the others in the Philips Innovation Fellows Competition.
  • Interested in collaborating on the project?  Contact me through my website.
  • For reading down to here… THANK YOU!
story_txt:
Short Summary

Regardless of who the steering committee has chosen, this was the most innovative, most meaningful, and best entry in the Philips Innovation Fellows / Bloomberg News Next Big Thing competition.  
See for yourself at: http://www.indiegogo.com/partners/philips


This campaign is closed.  You can still help by visiting me at:
fundrazr.com/campaigns/7cHe4/ab/61mkb2

My name is Robert DeDomenico.  For over three years now, I have been developing a prototype system for the automated utility transport of small payloads, such as a gallon of milk, or a loaf of bread.  At a cost of only $4,500 so far, the major design work, most of the construction of the first vehicle subassembly, and construction of the first section of test track are already complete.  I am a lifelong tinkerer.  I grew up on a farm and began experiencing equipment maintenance and repair from a young age.  I have been a submariner, electronics technician, nuclear operator, and computer scientist, and have actively enjoyed the hobbies of model railroading, bicycling, sailing, windsurfing, hang gliding, scuba diving, and RC cars & helicopters.  
My goal is to change the world by revolutionizing the way we transport solid physical objects, to help us live well, stay healthy, and enjoy life.  Winning first place will help me achieve this.

I will complete the first demonstration prototype system, and use this demonstrator to win private and government backing for a first real service installation.  I have just submitted an application to the New York State Energy Research Development Authority (NYSERDA), Program Opportunity Notice 2781 Advanced Transportation Concepts.  I will also be submitting an abstract to the US Department of Energy Unsolicited Proposal Program.  Success in this campaign will enhance each of these applications.
Implementation of this technology will revolutionize the way we shop for groceries, get prescriptions, send and receive the mail, discard trash… move any small payload in general… down the block, around town or across state.  It will reduce miles driven in America by between 5% and 10%, with a proportional drop in traffic congestion, accident rates, and demand for petroleum fuel.  As containerized freight has done in long haul transport, this technology will will do in "last mile" distribution, reducing handling costs and final prices while improving the availability and variety of goods to us all.

Some background on the problem and solution:  In America, we consume about 100 quadrillion BTU's of energy per year.  (Global consumption is about 500 quads.)  About 40% of this is oil, and about two thirds of that is for transportation.  In addition to moving people, vehicles of course transport materials and goods.  Energy to move materials and goods is typically boiled down to units of BTU's consumed per ton of payload per mile of transport, or BTU per ton-mile.  The most efficient movement of material and goods is by water, rail, and pipeline, all typically on the order of a few hundred BTU/ton-mile.  The US trucking industry moves payloads for a few thousand BTU/ton-mile.  When we move goods with our cars though, we are using a few thousand BTU's per mile whether we are carrying anything or not, and how often are we carrying a ton of goods?  Let's take an example of driving to the local sandwich shop in the morning for some breakfast sandwiches and a gallon of milk.  The milk weighs a whopping 8 pounds, and the sandwiches might add up to another pound, but let's just say two.  The whole payload then is 10 lbs, or 1/200th of a ton.  If the car were a Prius getting 57 mpg, it is still burning 2,000 BTU per mile.  So the payload is moving for 400,000 BTU per ton mile... one way!  (The driver had to make a round trip.)  The CargoFish system will be able to move this same payload for about 20 BTU's per mile.  (That's energy burned at the electric plant, and counting all the losses of conversion to electricity, distribution, and vehicle efficiency.)  Our almost universal assumption that in order to move anything any reasonable distance on an immediate basis requires a car, is actually incorrect.  It requires moving only what matters, and as little else as possible.  Imagine if we all had to transport every gallon of water home as if from the grocery store.  Driving it all wouldn't be a very effective solution, would it?  Please feel free to ask about any concerns you have.  My concern is that it is unsustainable to continue putting thousands of pounds of motorized machinery in motion every time we want to get a few pounds from here to there.  I think we can do better, and I hope you agree because I need your vote to win first place, which will help immensely with getting a faster pace going on developing and implementing this technology.  Thank you very much.  I will not let you down.
What We Need & What You Get

In order to prove the technical and fiscal feasibility of this system well enough to warrant investment, people are going to need to see it.  I need to complete the demonstration prototype of about 400 feet of track and at least one vehicle.  The current material cost for track adds up to $6 per foot, totaling $2,400 for this phase.  I also need to progress the first vehicle, whose first wheel set is nearly done, by finishing this assembly, building another identical wheel set, then constructing the main body frame and assembling all three into a completed vehicle.  The motor, controller, wheels, racks, gears, pulleys, belts, bearings, shafts, fasteners, and frame materials for the first wheel set totaled about $1,000.  Another $1,000 will be needed for the second wheel set assembly.  My present estimate for the components and materials necessary to complete the main frame, assemble these three into one vehicle, and install an initial control system is another $600.  With this total of $4,000 for parts and materials, I will be able to complete a system able to demonstrate semi-autonomous control of one vehicle over any emulated arbitrary path.
I have a website for the project, where I will post a list of every contributor to this campaign.  Every contributor will be invited to selected project milestone(s), such as first public demonstration.  Other perks include bundle(s) of free service, redeemable when this system becomes available at the contributors'  primary abode, vacation house, or place of business.  (See the specific perks for details.)
The first $1,600 of funds raised will go toward completion of the first vehicle.
The next $2,400 of funds raised will go toward test track construction.
Additional winnings will be used to build 3 additional vehicles.
Funds beyond that will be used carefully, in support of the project.


The Impact
This project will raise our standard of living.  This technology is the closest thing to the Star Trek transporter that the world will ever realize.  It will become the Physical Internet, connecting most households in the US.  Even before reaching that level of adoption, early installations in senior living complexes will restore a significant measure of self-sufficiency to many of us as we age, as independent travel by driving or otherwise becomes more inconvenient, difficult, or altogether impossible.  Other early adoption communities will have residents enjoying more free time as they do not find themselves compelled to travel for needs that must be met more immediately than mail order, Fedex, or UPS.  Businesses will exchange documents and/or other physical objects at levels of service exceeding the best and fastest courier companies, at a fraction of the cost.  More workers will be able to telecommute because they will not be limited to exchanging only voice and information over the telephone and Internet.  Because this technology will prove worth installing, an entire industry will grow to install, maintain, and expand it, providing local construction, maintenance, operation and administration jobs wherever it goes.  The reduction in transportation fuel consumption will boost the economy.  In addition to small payloads, all of these benefits can be delivered by this technology.
This will be no more expensive than municipal water or sewer.  Those systems involve miles of underground infrastructure, yet are the most effective and inexpensive way to deliver water and remove waste.  The household bill for those services is low enough that most people have to look it up to tell me how much it costs.  Don't jump to premature conclusions about something "totally not plausible", or too expensive to prove practical.  Infrastructure does cost, but returns enormous value, and, spread out over millions of customers the costs are more affordable than the alternative of doing without.  Please take the time to browse the comments, where I have re-posted several of my favorite correspondences received.
I’ve recently given a presentation to the Rowan University Honors Engineering class of 2016, as well as another to several officials at the New York State Energy Research Development Authority.
Your contribution: financial, comments, or just spreading awareness, will help me accelerate development, build and prove this technology.  
Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you can’t contribute financial support, I could still use your help:

Please spread the word. 

Like this campaign page, tweet this campaign page, etc.


Like my facebook page: CargoFish Physical Internet


Offer your comments, or ask any questions. here, or through the contact form on my website: www.cargofish.com.
Compare my campaign to the others in the Philips Innovation Fellows Competition.

Interested in collaborating on the project?  Contact me through my website.

story:
Two Tasty Ladies Catering and Events Start Up Campaign

Two Tasty Ladies have banded together to create a large, vintage style, charge at your next event!  We need your help to make this happen!

What’s Our Tale, Nightingale?

We are Suzanne and Shawna, co-owners of Two Tasty Ladies Catering and Events.  Our style is way out, never square, and our service is straight up and vintage!  Our events are made in the shade so all you need to do is make the scene!

Translation:  Our goal is to facilitate unique and inviting event experiences through our interpersonal and vintage style services. 

Two Tasty Ladies has already begun to establish itself in the catering community.  We have provided catering and decor services for several clients and have successfully navigated a large, live band and dance for approximately 300 people.  We have several bookings in the works for the next few months and have been invited to join several community events throughout the city of Toronto.  Up to this point, we have had to rely on rental kitchens for food production and the use of our own homes for equipment storage.

Once fully established in our own location, with your help, Two Tasty Ladies will be able to provide jobs for upwards of 50 staff and will be able to support our local charities of choice and abroad.  We have decided that a portion of our profits from every event will be set aside for The Bequia Mission.  The Bequia Mission is a strictly volunteer, non-profit, registered Canadian charity which supports over 15 different charitable organizations throughout St. Vincent and the Grenadines providing food services for the elderly, school supplies for schools, medicine for hospitals, clinics, children with HIV/AIDS hospices and much more.

Let Us Clue You In – We’ll Give it to you Straight!

We need to raise $15,000 to help cover the start up costs for our dream company.  These costs include:

  • Licensing and Insurance
  • Marketing tools and Web hosting
  • Incorporation
  • Supplies and Equipment

Your generous donations will help launch our dream and support us in our first few months.  As we establish our business, we will be able to start giving back to our community and The Bequia Mission.

In exchange, we are offering Tasty Perks such as: discounted services, gift certificates, free canapés and gift baskets.

If you want your dollars to go further, you can choose not to receive a perk.  Either way, you know you are helping build a dream and make a difference in many people’s lives at home here in Toronto and abroad.

Dig what we do, but don’t have the bread?

We also accept your words of support and encouragement, your belief in us and our causes and your help to share our dream with your family and friends.

Please use the share tools here on Indiegogo and other social media outlets such as Facebook, Twitter and personal emails to get the word out.  We appreciate every little bit of help we receive!

Find us – the Two Tasty Ladies Catering & Events on Facebook, Twitter, and on our website, www.twotastyladies.ca.

Credit where credit is due:

Big love to DJC Designs, the creative genius behind all of our print and digital media, and to Richard Freitas for creating the music in our infomercial.   We would also like thank all of our friends and family for their undying love and support.

story:
My name is Evan Louie and I am the owner of Kona Ice Las Vegas and Henderson. We are reaching out to everyone to help us build a brighter future for Clark County AND our children. Our team believes in building a stronger community.

Our now over $10 million and Counting Dollar Giveback To Our Community Video
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0PlveKjOr6M&feature=channel&list=UL

 

4 years ago, I lost my wife, Cheryl Fernandez Louie, to brain cancer and she was survived by our daughter Cevan who is now 5. My late wife handled tourism for Hawaii Visitors and Convention Bureau, runner up Miss Hawaii, academic scholar with a Political Science Degree from University of Hawaii, Woman of the Year, and devoted to her faith and philanthopy for helping others. Since she passed, I devoted our passion to making a difference in others lives and building a legacy for our daughter's future. We are devoted to this cause in memory of those we love dearly lost to cancer. We also lost her father last year and my father is diagnosed with terminal Gall Bladder cancer stage 4.

Interview in Hawaii networks on NBC and ABC in studio about brain tumor awareness and Kennedy Bill 717 when Senator Kennedy passed of brain cancer:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cR9MeYABWKY

As a team, we strive to help change the state of educational standards for our youth with Nevada being ranked 50 out of 50 in the U.S., a near 50% high school drop out rate, and the need for pursuit of higher level education. In the first two weeks of our launch in May 2012, we gave out thousands of FREE SHAVED ice to teachers as a token of appreciation to the educators in our community to every elementary and middle school in 9 zip codes. We didn't sell a single shaved ice in the first two weeks. Both my business partner, James Zhang, who lost his father to cancer, and I have not taken a single dime in salary because we believe in the future of Kona Ice Las Vegas and Henderson.

Interview on Channel 8 News about Kona Ice Las Vegas launch:http://www.8newsnow.com/category/28259/8-news-now-video?clipId=7655230&autostart=true

Since our launch, we now have hundreds of partners including over 60 schools, largest sports associations / leagues, non-profits, largest churches, community centers, universities, chambers of commerce, civic organizations, corporations, and retail strip malls. Kona Ice Las Vegas & Henderson has received awards from UNLV, Opportunity Village, Mayor of Las Vegas Carolyn Goodman, U.S. Congressional Award from Dina Titus, commendation award from U.S. Senator Harry Reid, and even invited to the Presidential Inauguration by the Presidential Inauguration committee. All in one year with ONE shaved ice truck, hundred plus volunteers across the cities and other states, and the belief in making our community stronger. As a national brand, we have won #1 Entrepreneur Franchise 500 in the entire U.S.. As owners of Kona Ice Las Vegas and Henderson, we also own the largest territory in the U.S. comprised of 11 franchise territories.

Our target goals is to raise a target minimum of $432,000 and if we reach $826,000 it would meet our full fleet deployment across our 11 territories. The funding will be used for 1.) Working capital for salaries of event coordination / community organizers, recruitment of Full-Time and Part-Time employees, marketing operational expenses 2.) Acquisition of Kona Entertainment Vehicles and carts 3.) Sponsoring events for underprivileged children and families 4.) Extremely cost efficient budget of keynote speakers, celebrities, and additional travel and expense costs to promote education in our community in our schools.

Our devotion brings well known celebrities, national keynote speakers, academic scholars, and successful entrepreneurs to speak at elementary schools to universities like UNLV. Our goal is to inspire our younger generations to pursue higher education in the university systems, find their ambitions, and invest in our human capital. We have done this with a shoe string budget and relationships built in the national community while still maintaining profitability. We have over 100+ people in the community help volunteer with us as we run as a hybrid of a volunteer non-profit, grassroots organizing campaign, and for profit entrepreneurial venture with social responsibility. We have a very sustainable business model that has a 100% successfully proven track record for over 200 franchisees across the entire U.S. since our inception in 2007.

By partnering with the private sector and non-profits, we have created an open platform for businesses to adopt social responsibility and philanthropy. We, the community, believe that if we can converge all our partners together it will eventually lead to solidarity and strengthen community building in Southern Nevada via a horizontal and vertical community integration platform. Hence, the concept of paying it forward to others.

Devotion to Communities (40+ States) Across the County Preview Trailer
http://vimeo.com/61044274

We have also built an entrepreneurial mentoring program within Kona Ice Las Vegas and Henderson to help aspiring business owners learn the fundamentals of building a nationwide company. Coming from a background of working with Fortune 500 and Global 2000 companies, we have advised executive directors / senior management of non-profits, start-ups, and small businesses learn best practices in sales methodologies, operational strategies, brand promotion, value propositions, and building a roadmap to success.

What if you can invest into charity via a hybrid of venture philanthropy? What if you can help multiple charites instead of just one? Or build the infrastructure for non-profit fundraising? What if you can invest in education for our future generations? Your contributions changes the lives of many as we have heavily invested into the community. Since we donate 20% of our top line sales revenue, the GREATEST thing is that it is a recurring donation so it is the GIFT that just KEEPS GIVING.

If you are a business / company, show your support for all our schools, sports leagues, non-profits, churches, and gain exposure to hundreds of thousands by our social responsibility co-branding. We fundraise at many of the largest events with thousands to tens of thousands even on a daily basis. You will gain brand marketing and community recognition all across the cities. In addition, learn how our World Changing Humanitarian and other options can benefit from our partnerships. It is proven that social responsibility brands, empathy based marketing to consumers, and giving back to community helps build loyalty. You can decide on what charities to fundraise for, be present at our giveback check events, and be recognized for building a better Southern Nevada.

If you are a non-profit, you can join the crowdfundraising team. If you raise enough for an ENTIRE Kona Ice Cart or Kona Ice Entertainment Vehicle, your charity will benefit from our dedicated private events with even greater percentages going back to your charity. If you are a registered 501(c)3 non-profit, you can sell our $12 giftcards online for the Giveback program via our crowdfunding site. 20% will go back (we incur 7% - 12% in fees here) to your charity by the donor indicating in notes who benefits. Offer good only to Kona Ice Las Vegas & Henderson events. Great for churches or other non-profits with dedicated fundraising and we do all the work! We invite all those who would like to join to make it a viral campaign!

You can also make anonymous donation or any increments that are not listed by the Perks section. We do need your shipping information for certain perks to make sure we can contact you!

For those who are company based sponsorships or philanthropists that contribute $10,000 or more, please inquire about how your company can benefit via our strategic alliances with the owners of Kona Ice Las Vegas and Henderson. 

You can also help by spreading the word, forwarding this link to all your friends and family. It takes people like yourself who seek to make a difference in this world as humanitarians. We know that YOU CAN make that difference in other peoples lives. We have testimonials from hundreds of key community leaders who believe in us, thank you for your trust in our dream to build a brighter future for Clark County. It is not investing in Kona Ice Las Vegas and Henderson, it is helping expand to invest more in our community and change the lives of more people via philanthropy.

Please take some time to review the pictures in our gallery to know our dedication to building our community!

 Evan Louie, Cevan Louie, James "Qin" Zhang, and all our Kona Ice community volunteers

Owners of Kona Ice Las Vegas & Henderson

Linkedin Profile: http://www.linkedin.com/profile/view?id=1928494...

Our goal is to inspire our younger generations to pursue higher education in the university systems, find their ambitions, and invest in our human capital. We have done this with a shoe string budget and relationships built in the national community while still maintaining profitability. We have over 100+ people in the community help volunteer with us as we run as a hybrid of a volunteer non-profit, grassroots organizing campaign, and for profit entrepreneurial venture with social responsibility. We have a very sustainable business model that has a 100% successfully proven track record for over 200 franchisees across the entire U.S. since our inception in 2007.
By partnering with the private sector and non-profits, we have created an open platform for businesses to adopt social responsibility and philanthropy. We, the community, believe that if we can converge all our partners together it will eventually lead to solidarity and strengthen community building in Southern Nevada via a horizontal and vertical community integration platform. Hence, the concept of paying it forward to others.

Devotion to Communities (40+ States) Across the County Preview Trailerhttp://vimeo.com/61044274

We have also built an entrepreneurial mentoring program within Kona Ice Las Vegas and Henderson to help aspiring business owners learn the fundamentals of building a nationwide company. Coming from a background of working with Fortune 500 and Global 2000 companies, we have advised executive directors / senior management of non-profits, start-ups, and small businesses learn best practices in sales methodologies, operational strategies, brand promotion, value propositions, and building a roadmap to success.
What if you can invest into charity via a hybrid of venture philanthropy? What if you can help multiple charites instead of just one? Or build the infrastructure for non-profit fundraising? What if you can invest in education for our future generations? Your contributions changes the lives of many as we have heavily invested into the community. Since we donate 20% of our top line sales revenue, the GREATEST thing is that it is a recurring donation so it is the GIFT that just KEEPS GIVING.
If you are a business / company, show your support for all our schools, sports leagues, non-profits, churches, and gain exposure to hundreds of thousands by our social responsibility co-branding. We fundraise at many of the largest events with thousands to tens of thousands even on a daily basis. You will gain brand marketing and community recognition all across the cities. In addition, learn how our World Changing Humanitarian and other options can benefit from our partnerships. It is proven that social responsibility brands, empathy based marketing to consumers, and giving back to community helps build loyalty. You can decide on what charities to fundraise for, be present at our giveback check events, and be recognized for building a better Southern Nevada.
If you are a non-profit, you can join the crowdfundraising team. If you raise enough for an ENTIRE Kona Ice Cart or Kona Ice Entertainment Vehicle, your charity will benefit from our dedicated private events with even greater percentages going back to your charity. If you are a registered 501(c)3 non-profit, you can sell our $12 giftcards online for the Giveback program via our crowdfunding site. 20% will go back (we incur 7% - 12% in fees here) to your charity by the donor indicating in notes who benefits. Offer good only to Kona Ice Las Vegas & Henderson events. Great for churches or other non-profits with dedicated fundraising and we do all the work! We invite all those who would like to join to make it a viral campaign!
You can also make anonymous donation or any increments that are not listed by the Perks section. We do need your shipping information for certain perks to make sure we can contact you!
For those who are company based sponsorships or philanthropists that contribute $10,000 or more, please inquire about how your company can benefit via our strategic alliances with the owners of Kona Ice Las Vegas and Henderson. 
You can also help by spreading the word, forwarding this link to all your friends and family. It takes people like yourself who seek to make a difference in this world as humanitarians. We know that YOU CAN make that difference in other peoples lives. We have testimonials from hundreds of key community leaders who believe in us, thank you for your trust in our dream to build a brighter future for Clark County. It is not investing in Kona Ice Las Vegas and Henderson, it is helping expand to invest more in our community and change the lives of more people via philanthropy.
Please take some time to review the pictures in our gallery to know our dedication to building our community!
 Evan Louie, Cevan Louie, James "Qin" Zhang, and all our Kona Ice community volunteers
Owners of Kona Ice Las Vegas & Henderson
Linkedin Profile: http://www.linkedin.com/profile/view?id=1928494...

story:
Our Objective

We intend to restore & protect The Boilers & Millcreek Canyon in Washington, Utah. To create a place that people are drawn to because of it’s intrinsic beauty, rich history, educational opportunities, & artistic displays.

We have an opportunity to bridge our past with our future in a really meaningful way. Supporting an organization that will serve community needs, enhance educational experiences, create positive job growth in this region, and showcase the inherent beauty and significance of important historical sites seems like a no-brainer.

Our Story

There is a treasure, a literal oasis in the arid convergence of the Mojave Desert, the Colorado Plateau, and the Great Basin geological zones.  Water sources that have fed our hometown for generations. First impacted by the construction of the I-15 freeway in the 1960's, these sites began a marked decline over the ensuing decades.  Once places of community gathering and innocent recreation, these sites have been neglected and polluted. They have been closed down from public access, but continue to be trespassed upon and have a reputation for vagrancy, drug use, and obvious vandalization.

We have been struck with a profound sense of the potential of these sites to be restored as a spaces of beauty and productivity.  Our intent is to create a place for the local and international community to connect.  A place that people are attracted to because of the intrinsic beauty, rich history, educational opportunities, and breath taking artistic displays.

These sites, known as The Boilers & Millcreek, have been important to our community historically,  They continue to provide an important source of fresh water to the residents of Southern Utah.  They are home to a diverse range of plants & wildlife and also boast Native American ruins and petroglyphs.  We plan to create gardens, a conservatory, and trail system to restore honor & beauty to what has been damaged, defaced, and almost forgotten.

Two years ago our group began researching in earnest the possibility of creating a public botanical garden which lead us to the American Public Garden Association's National Convention. It was hosted by Franklin Gardens in Columbus, Ohio. Our eyes were opened to the way a public garden can transform a community. Subsequent visits to the Phipps Conservatory in Pittsburg gave us the opportunity to engage with the staff of the conservatory and we were further energized to see leadership in sustainable building and technology. We knew this was a pattern for what we wanted to bring to our hometown...and we have a plan.

The Boiling Springs Ecoseum & Desert Preserve was born.  It is a non-profit entity created in 2012 to address the ecological concerns of The Boilers & Millcreek Canyon in Washington, Utah.   

The Impact

From every angle, the Boiling Springs Ecoseum & Desert Preserve is a learning environment. Far more than a public garden, The Ecoseum will serve as a center for teaching, learning, and research.  Visitors from around the world will be immersed in the cultural heritage as well as the unique natural history of Southern Utah.  Moreover, the very infrastructure of the facilities will serve as a functional example of the most advanced applications of technology, engineering, architecture, and environmentally sustainable practices. As our world faces increasingly more complex challenges, The Ecoseum will represent the potential of human ingenuity and technological promise.

Our region is known the world over for its National Parks and boasts an impressive annual eco-tourism tally.  We find this presents a wonderful opportunity for our local and international community to leave an indelible impression on one another.


IT ALL BEGINS HERE....

We have chosen to begin our fundraising efforts with an Indiegogo campaign because we believe it embodies the very spirit we aim to create; a community that reaches out to one another to support and build something greater that they could achieve on their own.  We need each other, we all need to contribute to something meaningful even if that contribution is just a drop in the proverbial bucket.  It all makes a difference.

WHAT HAPPENS NEXT....

Your generous contributions demonstrate public support of this project. The funds we raise from this campaign will go towards Phase I:

  • Site Studies and Remediation (clean up & restoration)

  • Site Engineering and Design

  • Legal and Accounting Costs

  • Historical Research and Preservation

Any funds raised above and beyond our goal will help accelerate our Phase I development and go towards the acquisition of additional properties necessary for future phases.


REWARDS...

We wanted to find perks that are as extraordinary as The Boilers.  The kinds of things one doesn't just happens across everyday.  They are reflective of our mission and will serve as a reminder of your connection to us and our connection to you.

This is a project that will not just impact a little area in Southern Utah, this is something that can literally help change the world. One of the best things you can contribute is your voice and your time.  If funds are tight do your part by sharing this campaign on your social media profiles or contact us via email at theboilingsprings@gmail.com to see how you can volunteer get involved.

story:
Our Story

Starting a small business is such a leap of faith.  Our internet business turned from a fun hobby in to a full-fledged option for a career, and we decided to branch out into not only a retail location, but a fully functioning art studio where the community can come and learn to re-purpose and refinish their own furniture. 

We searched for over a year, and found the perfect space. Perfect in theory, that is!  It had terrible termite damage, uneven concrete floors, mold, peeling paint...you get the idea! Not afraid of hard work, we jumped right in, working 12 hour days, sometime more.  Our "Grand Opening" was on track for November 1st. 

With less than two weeks to go, one half of Stiltskin Studios, Kenny, was in a motorcycle accident.  With a hospital stay, broken bones, and a lengthy recovery time, we contemplated throwing in the towel, but as the proverbial "they" say, if it was easy ,everyone would be doing it. We made the commitment to somehow make it happen. 

Part retail space, part art studio...

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal was initially just to figure out how to get our doors open, but we've raised enough capital for that.  Our new goal? To pay it forward by way of free art classes for kids...we want to bring that creative spark, the beauty of creating something, to the kids that might never get the experience.

What's in it for us?  Extra product, brushes, and supplies to be able to offer children's classes at no cost.

What's in it for you?  We can't offer jaw-dropping perks, sorry!  If we could, we wouldn't be here raising funds!  What we CAN offer is exposure...if you are a business owner, we can promote your business on our blog (www.stiltskinstudios.blogspot.com) and on our FaceBook page.

If you're local, we're offering a mini-class on furniture painting, or we'll credit your contribution amount toward any class, products, etc.

Not local?  You can apply your contribution towards a purchase in our Etsy shop.

  Of course, you'll also get the satisfaction of enabling us the chance to pay it forward!

The Impact

Our business is located in historic downtown Tarpon Springs.  Our street recently underwent a dramatic transformation from dilapidated and desperate to adorable...brick streets, new awnings, antique iron street lights and benches...it's lovely.  But the foot traffic just isn't there yet.  Other small businesses on our street are struggling.  Our long-term goal is to turn Hibiscus Street into DESTINATION shopping...and our business attracts destination shoppers. We're proud to be able to contribute to the rebirth of this "Main Street" in our community, and we aren't willing to let go because of a temporary, if major, setback. 


Don't have two nickels? 

Not everyone can contribute monetarily so if you aren't able, don't sweat it!  Can you help us spread the word by sharing this campaign on your social media outlets.

story:
The Story

I suppose you could say it started the same way just about everything does. With a girl. A girl in the tropics with sensitive skin that was forever in a state of itchiness and dryness. Fearing a severe skin condition, she visited her doctor and told him all about the problems she'd been having. The doctor asked several questions, but no solution was obvious or forthcoming. 

The girl went on with her daily activities, which on this particular day meant a trip to the grocery store. Casually filling her basket with daily essentials, she noticed that her commercial soap of choice had new packaging. Studying the new packaging lead to the startling realization that she couldn't pronounce most of the ingredients on the label. That girl, of course... was my wife.

With that, an idea was born. Simply made, 100% all natural soap. Free from chemical additives and preservatives. Cruelty free. Vegan friendly. People friendly. Safe. 

Our Products

Commercially made "soap" isn't actually soap at all. It consists entirely of artificial detergents, fillers, chemicals, petroleum, high animal fat content (read: sodium tallowate) and irritants like SLS or SLES (sulfates) that are harmful to people, animals,and the environment. They are not put in the product to improve its quality, but rather to prolong its shelf life. 

Our naturally made tropical soaps are made with this simple formula:

Oils + Butters + Lye = Soap

Living in the tropics for 7 years has given us great insight into another culture. Watching locals prepare handmade soaps and body care products (and testing them out, of course) has taught me one important thing. We're doing soap all wrong.

The first step towards incredible body treatments is to find the freshest and safest ingredients. My time abroad has allowed me the opportunity to cultivate relationships with the growers and purveyors of fresh fruit, vegetables and other plants that allow for the creation of the best handmade products around.

We use the highest quality fruit and vegetable based oils, butters and essences to produce a superior quality, luxuriously lathery soap. Nothing unnatural ever has, or will ever be added. The glycerin usually taken out of commercial soaps is left where it belongs in our soaps, which makes for a more moisturizing and nourishing cleansing experience.

We currently offer soaps with a great selection exfoliating tropical ingredients and an array of tropical scents that are sure to please the olfactory senses. Each product we make is lovingly hand crafted in small batches with each ingredient being 100% cruelty free. Our palm oils for example, are sourced from growers and processors who are members of the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO).

Each one of our soaps are between 3.5 ounces (100 grams) and 4.2 ounces (120 grams) depending on the ingredients and the exfoliating agent used. They are also available in larger loaf forms or bulk units, allowing you to decide exactly how big you want your bars and to reduce cost. 

Each tropical soap variety we offer comes in several different all natural scents made from pure fruit, vegetable, and plant oils. Some of our soaps contain great exfoliating agents such as oats, lemon rinds, poppy seeds, chamomile tea, green tea, aloe vera and freshly ground coffee. For a list of our most frequently asked for scents and exfoliating ingredients, don't hesitate to contact us.

We are also in the development stages of a line of tropical bath bombs and lip balms, made from the same high quality ingredients that make our fragrant and natural soap line so popular.

Where The Funds Go

The funds obtained through this project will be used to order the highest quality ingredients we can find. Many are USDA approved organic oils and butters, some are RSPO members, and all are vegan friendly and cruelty free. While our soaps currently use the exact same ingredients, they are costly to produce when buying in limited quantities. Some such bulk items cost in excess of $400/unit which makes moving forward without your support an impossibility. Purchasing ingredients in bulk will allow us the opportunity to reduce the price of our products by more than 50%, and expand the current business. Additionally, some of the funds will be used to purchase stronger curing racks and additional molds and cutters.

Indiegogo, You Say?

Indiegogo is a website that allows creative people to reach out to their friends, family, neighbors, and prospective customers the world over in order to help get ideas off the ground. Whether it's a musician pressing a new album, an inventor looking to fund a first production run, or an all natural hand made soap making company, each creator sets a goal to reach. If the total pledges don't reach the goal, then the project is not funded at all. The pledges aren't an investment in the business in that you don't get a share of the company. This fundraiser is just for the creation of our great line of products. 

Note: If we don't get 100% funded, we get nothing! None of the pledges come out of your accounts until we reach 100%, so please help us spread the word about our great 100% all natural soap! 

1. Create an Indiegogo account! All you'll need is an email address. 

2. Sign in if you already have an account, you're all set. If not it only takes a moment. 

 3. Pledge what you are comfortable giving. We appreciate every dollar. If you find yourself wanting to help but unable to donate you can skip to the next step to help us spread the word. Your card will only be charged should we reach our full goal. 

 4. SHARE this with your friends, family, coworkers, neighbors, and whoever else crosses your path!

story:
Dear Friends:

Saturday, August 31 ushers in a new era in the lives of Houston’s Third Ward residents! I am appealing to you to help open a much-needed natural food store in this community.

I have lived in the Third Ward most of my life and have benefited from the best this community offers. After graduating from college and returning to my beloved Houston, I asked myself, “How can I be of service to my community?”

Through my personal health journey, I found my life's mission: promoting health in my community through the creation of a natural food store in the Third Ward, which until now has been a veritable food desert. http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/organic-soul-foods

The Organic Soul Foods project sprang from our community's critical need to combat obesity, high blood pressure, diabetes and other health crises, and our desire for and right to easy access to delicious, high-quality fruits, vegetables, grains and proteins. This grocery and lifestyle store will feature a cornucopia  of good for you, good tasting, organic foods and natural products to enable you to prepare healthy meals at home. Additionally, this professionally managed store will include wholesome, already prepared food to take out and eat in at the in-store café, as well as regular classes on food preparation and healthy living designed to teach  our community how to eat and live better. 

At 4pm CST on August 31st, the Organic Soul Foods crowdfunding campaign was launched here on Indiegogo.com and in person at Houston’s Blue Triangle Community Center, 3005 McGowen Street.

The goal for this 40-day Indiegogo.com campaign is $40,000.  On day one, 3% of the goal was reached. Thank you to all those who already gave! In order to meet the total goal, we need to raise $1000/day for the rest of the campaign. This start-up money will assist us in securing a $160,000 bank loan. The total start-up cost is $200,000 and will be used to open the Organic Soul Foods store in 2014.

Contributors can give as little as a $1 and as much as $10,000 and the Organic Soul Foods project needs your support! During the campaign, I will send out emails and post the latest campaign news on Facebook. I ask that you share this information with interested friends and family. Also, please click here to "Like" Organic Soul Foods on Facebook and "Follow" us on Twitter.

For more information about the Organic Soul Foods project or this campaign, please visit http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/organic-soul-foods or www.organicsoulfoods.com. If you have  questions, please feel free to contact me at organicsoulfoods@gmail.com.

Thank you in advance for backing this endeavor. With your support, I know Organic Soul Foods will be a catalyst for healthy change in this community and beyond.

Yours in Food and Wellness,
Debra
story_txt:
Dear Friends:Saturday, August 31 ushers in a new era in the lives of Houston’s Third Ward residents! I am appealing to you to help open a much-needed natural food store in this community.I have lived in the Third Ward most of my life and have benefited from the best this community offers. After graduating from college and returning to my beloved Houston, I asked myself, “How can I be of service to my community?”Through my personal health journey, I found my life's mission: promoting health in my community through the creation of a natural food store in the Third Ward, which until now has been a veritable food desert. http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/organic-soul-foods
The Organic Soul Foods project sprang from our community's critical need to combat obesity, high blood pressure, diabetes and other health crises, and our desire for and right to easy access to delicious, high-quality fruits, vegetables, grains and proteins. This grocery and lifestyle store will feature a cornucopia  of good for you, good tasting, organic foods and natural products to enable you to prepare healthy meals at home. Additionally, this professionally managed store will include wholesome, already prepared food to take out and eat in at the in-store café, as well as regular classes on food preparation and healthy living designed to teach  our community how to eat and live better.  
At 4pm CST on August 31st, the Organic Soul Foods crowdfunding campaign was launched here on Indiegogo.com and in person at Houston’s Blue Triangle Community Center, 3005 McGowen Street. 
The goal for this 40-day Indiegogo.com campaign is $40,000.  On day one, 3% of the goal was reached. Thank you to all those who already gave! In order to meet the total goal, we need to raise $1000/day for the rest of the campaign. This start-up money will assist us in securing a $160,000 bank loan. The total start-up cost is $200,000 and will be used to open the Organic Soul Foods store in 2014.Contributors can give as little as a $1 and as much as $10,000 and the Organic Soul Foods project needs your support! During the campaign, I will send out emails and post the latest campaign news on Facebook. I ask that you share this information with interested friends and family. Also, please click here to "Like" Organic Soul Foods on Facebook and "Follow" us on Twitter.
For more information about the Organic Soul Foods project or this campaign, please visit http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/organic-soul-foods or www.organicsoulfoods.com. If you have  questions, please feel free to contact me at organicsoulfoods@gmail.com.Thank you in advance for backing this endeavor. With your support, I know Organic Soul Foods will be a catalyst for healthy change in this community and beyond.Yours in Food and Wellness,Debra

story:
Short Summary

We are Inertia Skate & Snowboard Shop. We are a family-run business consisting of Nick & Sharon Alfano & our sons, Nicholas & Riley. Nick has been a skateboarder & snowboarder all his life.  Last year our boys took up snowboarding and loved it! One day the perfect space opened up in downtown Midland. It was close to the Trilogy Skate Park & convenient to neighboring cities. We have been open for only a couple of months now & are fast approaching our first winter season. We need help raising funds to order the inventory necessary to make it a successful snow season. As you can imagine, ordering boots, coats, & snowboards by the dozens is very expensive! We are extremely excited about this winter and the success of our shop, but we need help!

What We Need & What You Get

The donations we receive will be used to purchase snowboards, boots, snowboarding coats & pants, hats, goggles, apparel, accessories, fixtures, & advertising. Our perks range from "Honorable Mention" of your name on a longboard displayed on our wall, to our elite perk of your choice of snowboard deck we have in stock. 

The Impact

The success of Inertia is critical to our community for a number of reasons.

      1.  We offer a fun, athletic outlet for families & people of all ages. 

      2.  Since we have young children & live in a family community, we promote

            a drug-free skate environment.

      3.  Since there are few skate/snowboard shops in our area, we help attract 

            visitors from other cities to the Midland area.

      4.   We look forward to being a successful part of the evolving downtown 

             community.

       5.   Our sons are learning the value of hard work & responsibility.

Risks & Challenges

If we are unable to reach our funding goal, we will not be able to provide our customers with the product they have already been requesting. This, in turn, will result in less money to be able to order our inventory for the following spring. It will create a financial "snowball effect" if we can't get started with the inventory we need.

Other Ways You Can Help

Just don't have the extra money to donate? You can help immensely just by spreading the word of this campaign to EVERYONE you know!

story:
WHO WE ARE

Arrupe Karuna Welcome Center is a foster home for children and young people with disabilities who come from poor families. Our main goal is the integration and empowerment of these boys and girls who are physically disabled through formal education, employment opportunities and instilling positive values and attitudes. The youngsters supported by the center either attend school, university or vocational training centers. 

There are 48 boys and girls with disabilities living in Arrupe Welcome Center, and 20 members of staff, also physically disabled, who take care of the maintenance and management of the center and its various activities. In addition to the education the students receive the center organizes academic extra classes (to complement what they study at school), English classes, computer classes, agriculture workshops, traditional Khmer dancing classes, and tennis classes and other sports.

The center also assists the students' and employees' families by providing them with micro-loans, household construction, health infrastructure and food security services.

The students and staff suffer from different kinds of physical disabilities, many of them being Land Mine, Cluster Munitions and other Explosive Remnants of War (ERW) amputees. We are fully committed to the "Ban Land Mines and Cluster Munitions" cause. In previous occasions, we have organized other events to promote Awareness Campaigns, such as “Push for Progress” (2011) and "Make it Happen” (2012).

GOAL OF THE CAMPAIGN

Students from Arrupe Welcome Center want to send an inspirational message of courage and determination to those who suffer, as well as demand the Government of Cambodia, and many other countries, to join the Convention on Cluster Munitions (CCM). We plan to achieve this goal by implementing an awareness campaign in which we aim to generate consciousness among people from different countries about Land Mine and Cluster Munitions issues.

This campaign is promoted in coordination with the International Campaign to Ban Land Mines (ICBL), the Cluster Munition Coalition (CMC), the Jesuit Refugee Service (JRS) and other international and local associations, leading NGOs in this field.

Join the Convention on Cluster Munitions!

THE SCENARIO 

Angkor Wat Half-Marathon, December 7th, 2014

The main action of our campaign will be to participate in the Angkor Wat Half-Marathon event promoting our message “We run to ban Cluster Munitions”. At the time this event takes place (December 7th 2014) we will have already started our awareness campaign and contacted many friends and participants who will support our cause.

A team of 45 students with disabilities from Arrupe Welcome Center will join the marathon “Run to Bun Cluster munitions” supporting the campaign. 

A large number of T-shits, bands and other promotional materials will be distributed starting from the week before the event and finishing on December 7th in Siem Reap. We attempt to display a stand from where we could hand out our giveaways and promotional information (flyers and cards, flags…)

The Angkor Wat Half-Marathon is the perfect scenario from where to share our message:

· It will be attended by more than 6,000 participants coming from over 50 different countries

· Local Governmental Authorities will also join this important event

· The race will be covered by a variety of local and international televisions and media companies

· The event is organized by a non-profit organization, who has showed its commitment to the cause of land mines and cluster munitions since its first edition, in 1996

WHAT ARE CLUSTER MUNITIONS?

Cluster munitions pose significant danger to civilians for two principal reasons: their impact at the time of use and their deadly legacy. Launched from the ground or dropped from the air, cluster munitions consist of containers that open and disperse submunitions indiscriminately over a wide area, claiming both civilian and military victims. Many explosive submunitions, also known as bomblets, fail to detonate as designed when they are dispersed, becoming defacto landmines that kill and maim indiscriminately long after the conflict has ended and create barriers to socio-economic development.

To prevent civilians from the effects of cluster munitions, Norway and other like-minded countries initiated a fast-track diplomatic process in 2007 aimed at creating a new international treaty. Working in partnership with UN agencies, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) and civil society grouped under the Cluster Munition Coalition (CMC), the Oslo Process resulted in the adoption in May 2008 of the Convention on Cluster Munitions (CCM).

After 20 states ratified, the Convention on Cluster Munitions entered into force on August 2010. It prohibits the use, production, transfer and stockpiling of cluster munitions. The convention also requires destruction of stockpiled cluster munitions within eight years, clearance of cluster munition remnants within 10 years, and assistance to victims, including those killed or injured by submunitions as well as their families and affected communities.

CAMBODIA AND CLUSTER MUNITIONS

Cambodia has estimated a contamination of Cluster Munition covering at least 489km2 of land. Particularly its eastern and northeastern areas, bordering Lao PDR and Vietnam, are affected by between 1.9 million and 5.8 million cluster munition remnants as a result of US aircraft dropping approximately 26 million explosive submunitions in Cambodia during the Vietnam War. In February 2011, Thailand’s use of cluster munitions in Cambodia’s northern province, Preah Vihear, resulted in additional submunition contamination over an area of approximately 1.5km2.

Cambodia is also one of the six countries “considered to have the largest number of cluster munition victims, with the challenge of the responsibility to address the needs of several thousands of survivors.” Despite not having yet joined the convention, Cambodia has recognized the need for victim assistance and has provided information to Convention on Cluster Munition States Parties on their efforts in this regard. Cambodia has reported on their implementation efforts in accordance with the convention’s specific requirements of planning, coordination and the integration of victim assistance into rights-based frameworks. (Statement of Cambodia, Convention on Cluster Munitions Third Meeting of States Parties, Oslo, 12 September 2012) However, Cambodia has not yet joined the Cluster Munition Convention (CMC) nor signed the Convention on Cluster Munitions (CCM).

According to a review by Handicap International (HI) of US bombing data, approximately 80,000 cluster munitions, containing 26 million submunitions, were dropped on Cambodia (1969–1973) and more than 414,000 cluster bombs, containing at least 260 million submunitions, were dropped on Lao PDR (1965–1973).

Cluster munition remnants in Cambodia include unexploded BLU-24, BLU-26, BLU-36, BLU-42, BLU-43, BLU-49, BLU-61, M42, M46, and M85 sub- munitions.55 As of April 2013, an ongoing baseline survey (BLS) identified 990 suspected cluster munition-contaminated areas covering an area of 489.23km2, particularly in southeastern Kratie province bordering Vietnam, northeastern Stung Treng province and northern Preah Vihear province. This figure is likely to rise as a result of survey of additional areas.

story:
Perseverance

I am a 75-year-old who has failed at every business that I started, including trying to raise funds through crowd funding on Indiegogo.  I owned a record company, a travel magazine, an import-export business, and a public relations consulting firm --all of which failed.  I never made a nickel in any of them.

Why do I persist?  The short answer is that it's my nature.  I am determined to prove--to myself as well as to others--that you can build something from nothing.

So here I am again, trying to start a business.  This time it's an online coffee company called Cafe Soul Coffee.  (See Cafe Soul Coffee).  What's different about Cafe Soul coffee, compared with all the other businesses I started, is that I'm not looking to make a whole lot of money to satisfy a bunch of investors or to get rich.  No, this time it's different:  This time I will be happy to raise only $6,000 -- $5,300 of which would  buy a coffee roasting machine, while the rest would purchase coffee beans and other supplies.  The beans will be purchased mostly from Fair Trade coffee growers in Ethiopia, Kenya and Tanzania.

I think I will be successful in business this time around because I have a feeling that a lot of you will want me to succeed, not so much to satisfy my ego, but because when I succeed, I can make a lot of speeches before young kids in the inner cities, where I grew up, about the virtue of perseverance and what it means in building character, as well as what it says about people sharing their resources-- whether its money, talent, or simply an idea--to realize a common goal.

What We Need & What You Get

In practical terms, I need to purchase a coffee roasting machine to create volume.  I can't penny pinch my way to success.  I'm too old for that.  To be successful in this business, I will need to sell to large grocery chains as well as to individual coffee aficionados.  I need to build brand loyalty.  A coffee roasting machine, or two or three, will help enormously, as opposed to the way I have been doing it by filling orders one at a time, as they come in.  I've gone over the figures a zillion times, and $6,000 will get me started.  I can make it from there.  As the business grows, I will buy extra machines, move from my basement location, and hire workers.

Perks?

For people who give from $25-$99, I will add your name to a page on our website as a valued donor.  For people who donate $100-$500, in addition to adding your name to our donors' page, I will send you a half-pound of the coffee of your choice each month for a year.  For people who donate $1,000 or more, I will name you as "patron" of Cafe Soul Coffee co., as well as send you a pound of coffee of your choice monthly for two years.  In addition, you will be sent a coffee mug, with the Cafe Soul logo on it, indicating your patron status.
Finally, if I fail to reach my goal this time, and depending on how far I fall short, I will donate all of the funds raised to Museum Africa, a 501 (c )(3) nonprofit I founded a few years ago to raise consciousness about the enormous contributions that ancient Africans made to world civilizations.

The Impact

In a year or so, if I am successful, I can begin telling the world how Indiegogo contributions helped create jobs--however few--in depressed neighborhoods.  I can go on talk shows and talk about grass root efforts of people helping people succeed.  I can write opt-ed pieces in local newspapers and make speeches before community groups extolling the virtues of people working together for a common good.  Perhaps my example can inspire others to form businesses in their neighborhoods.  Cafe Soul Coffee Company can lead to the creation of Starbucks-style coffee shops all across the world, as well as food companies that sell products other than coffee.  My success might also inspire out-of-work people to form co-ops and grow their own vegetables and herbs and sell them at local farmers' markets.  I, for one, will preach that.  The potential is enormous.

Risks & Challenges

The risks are minimal.  For one thing, I will be proactive and pursue contracts and account receivable orders from large grocery chains for, say, delivering as much as 1,000 pounds of coffee each month.  This strategy eliminates the risk of storing huge inventories of coffee beans.  We will sell on demand.  

At the same time, this strategy has the potential of creating dozens of jobs in depressed neighborhoods.  Truckers, roasters, salespeople, office workers can be hired.  

The challenge will be to convince the chains to accept our product.  To overcome that challenge, I will appeal to the social-conscious efforts that they and other like-minded corporations are making or have made.  

Other Ways You Can Help

For those people who just can't contribute money, you can help by:

  • Asking folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Using the Indiegogo share tools!
