story:
What's the Point?

Hello, I am KJ. It’s nice to meet you! Project Offspring was born out of a dual reaction of love and frustration. I am a fan of social media as are most of my friends and family. The reason I have so much passion for this project is because as much as I love the community involved in social media, I have yet to find a place that is truly there for everyone.

There seems to be an overwhelming amount of bigotry that is overlooked and often encouraged on some of these sites. The Offspring Project is hoping to change that.

Everyone needs and deserves a safe place to be creative, vent, have fun, meet new people and/or just relax after a hard day.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $35,000. This was the bare minimum we can operate with. We have set our goal at $37,700 to cover the Indigogo fees. After fees, if we meet our goal, we will have $35,061.

When we say “Bare minimum” that’s what we mean! The person building this site, Jonathan Miller,  has been kind enough to do the job at a more than 50% discount of his normal rate. It’s good to have friends that care! Luckily, he believes in this project so deeply that he is willing to work at such a low rate to make this a reality. He has even set up a boutique site for the project!

This amount would cover three things specifically:

  1. The building/maintaining of the site for one year.
  2. The cost of a dedicated server for one year.
  3. The cost of a second person (in addition to KJ who is working for free) to work part time to help keep the site safe for all users.

Let’s Talk Perks!

  • Email Updates- We’ll send out special email updates to all donors. We will be making private, donor only, announcements and letting you know about the progress the site is making.
  • Special Preview- You get in first! After the Beta testing is finished, you’ll get a chance to get in and play around before the general public sees anything! You get to be a part of a special group that get’s to have a first look!
  • Beta Tester- You get to try to break things! Okay, no not really. But...sort of! You get to go in and play, tell us what you like and don’t like. Suggest changes or additions. Yes, you even get to try to “Break things!” We want to know that the site is going to stand up to just about everything and you’ll get to see if it actually does!
  • Charity Vote- Two months after the site is active to the public, we are going to start the $1 charity. Every month, there will be a different charity to donate to. People are constantly saying that people don’t/can’t make a difference online. I think we can prove them wrong! You will get a say in which charities we donate to in the first year!
  • Undying Appreciation- This goes without saying but I’ll say it anyway. THANK YOU! WE APPRECIATE YOU! The amount of affection people have shown for this project in such a short amount of time has let me and everyone working with me know that not only is there a want for this but a need. I am confident that this site can help to fill a void that none of us should have. We all deserve to feel safe. Every single one of us. Also, please know that we do realize that not everyone can give financially. If this is something you are interested in but can't give dollars, helping us get the word out is a fantastic way to help. The appreciation is certainly not limited to those with a bank account. To those that have already been so passionate and kind in the starting of this project, I thank you. We thank you. We can and will make a difference.

If we do not meet our initial goal, the plans will still go forth. If the total is not met, we will take whatever we do get and do as much as possible with what we have. We will also continue fund-raising. This is a project that I and everyone involved are passionate about. Everyone deserves a safe place.

The Impact

The impact we hope to make is to help fill an ugly void. Many of us do not have a safe haven in our every day lives. Unfortunately, our online lives aren’t often much different. This project hopes to change that. Yes, it is just another social site. At least, we hope that is how it feels. If we have done our jobs correctly, you won’t even have to think about your safety. You will just be safe. That safety will allow you to be creative. That safety will allow you to vent your frustrations without fear of retaliation. That safety will allow you to...relax. At least, a little bit. 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can’t donate money? How about a quick reblog on Tumblr? You can’t donate money? How about a quick link on Facebook? You can’t donate money? How about telling someone you know?

Money is not easy to come by. Most people just don’t have it to give. If you are one of those people, you can be just as big a help to us as those that can donate money. Talk about us. Tell anyone you can. You might not be able to donate money but your time is your wealth. Your word is your donation. We need you. If you have a dollar or if you the time. We need you.

story:
Alex Wrekk and Derek Neuland have joined forces to create Portland Button Works and zine distro!  With a collective 15 years of button making experience and over a million buttons pressed, we feel our custom button making skills would be even more awesome if we worked together.  Both of our lives are very intertwined with zines. We are both fans and creators of zines and we are hosts of a zine podcast (Nobody Cares About Your Stupid Zine Podcast) and organizers of the Portland Zine Symposium, we thought it was natural for us to start a zine distro as a part of this new business.

Will Portland Button Works just be another custom button business and zine distro?  No, it will be much more than that! As well as an online store, we are also going to be opening a physical storefront with the next month or 2 in Portland, Oregon.  Along with zines and buttons (in three different sizes!) we will also offer people the ability to make their own buttons right there in the store.  Another unique thing we will be offering is same day service on custom button orders (which we think people will love as a last minute gift or great for bands traveling through who ran low on merch).  We have a lot of other tricks up our sleeves, such as bike delivery, button making parties in the store, and much more.

The rewards we are offering for your support of Portland Button Works range from receiving one of our zines, pre-ordering some of our fine custom products, or getting an exclusive 10%, 20%, or 25% off our custom items for life! Every little bit helps.

We need your help to make this project a reality and would love it if you could spread the word to help make our dream a reality by using the Indieagogo share tools to help us out. We have all our business forms filled out and are looking at a space already. We are hoping to raise funds to assist with all the assorted costs that come along with opening a storefront from fixtures to maybe even new button machines and parts! We are, even now, getting new zines for the distro tuning up our machines to make buttons for you!

story:
**UPDATE**

When we first started this project we dreamed of the possibility of feeding all 400 families at Washington Shores. In an effort to not be over-ambitious we set a goal of 150 turkeys. After a month of campaigning different corporations, grocery stores, turkey farms, and other markets we were no closer to being able to afford turkeys for these families than on the day we started.

In less than 24 hours you have changed EVERYTHING. To say that we are overwhelmed with the generous support that this project has gotten, would be  a severe understatement.

 We have reached our initial goal and our now diligently reworking our entire project in an effort to feed AS MANY FAMILIES AS POSSIBLE in the Washington Shores Elementary community. Your continued support and donations are a blessing and will ALL continue to go to the Washington Shores community this Thanksgiving.

Thank you again. 

 

New goal: $3,000 to provide all 400 Washington Shores families with turkeys this Thanksgiving. 

Washington Shores is a school, with hard working teachers, an incredible student body, and increasing budget cuts. The school struggles to keep its doors open with its state "D" rating and almost non-existent funding. The community relies on this school as a safe place for the children of Washington Shores to be and learn.

  • 92% of the students are below the poverty line.
  • 100% of the students are minorities.
  • 100% of the students recieve free lunch provided by the school.

We are asking for a $7 donation to help us in our goal of feeding 150 families with Thanksgiving dinner this November. We are currently coordinating a food drive in our own neighborhoods, holding ticket drawings, and hosting a garage sale to collect funds for these dinners- but we're struggling to be able to afford turkeys for these children and their families.

Please, donate however little or much you can. Forgo a cup of coffee, and help make this holiday truly special for a community in need.

Thank you for all your kindness.

Happy Thanksgiving.

92% of the students are below the poverty line.
100% of the students are minorities.
100% of the students recieve free lunch provided by the school.
We are asking for a $7 donation to help us in our goal of feeding 150 families with Thanksgiving dinner this November. We are currently coordinating a food drive in our own neighborhoods, holding ticket drawings, and hosting a garage sale to collect funds for these dinners- but we're struggling to be able to afford turkeys for these children and their families.
Please, donate however little or much you can. Forgo a cup of coffee, and help make this holiday truly special for a community in need.
Thank you for all your kindness.
Happy Thanksgiving.

story:
Why Gardens?
Because gardens produce healthier food. Only 2% of American children eat enough fruits and vegetables, and 1 in 3 American children born after 2000 is at risk for Type II diabetes. A garden is an introduction to the real, healthy food students and families need access to.

Because gardens can help fix America's nature deficit. With more than 80% of Americans living in cities and suburbs, we need to work harder than ever to teach the values of natural processes.

Because gardens are a living laboratory for education. Not just healthy food—a lesson on what producing healthy food requires. Not just exposure to nature—a way for children to literally harvest the fruits of their labor.

A True Seed Investment 
For as little as $10, you can help a community reap all the benefits a garden has to offer. In just 39 days, we plan to raise $2500 per garden; to feed,  teach, and inspire people in each of these 100 communities. Here are a few things our garden plans to do with your donations:

The Crutcho School garden currently consists of ten 4x10 raised beds and a small hoop house constructed recently by a local church group. This summer, the garden was tended by school staff members and produced tomatoes, basil, melons, and peppers for summer school students to enjoy. During the 2012-2013 school year, Crutcho students will be working with staff members from the Regional Food Bank of Oklahoma's Urban Harvest program to learn more about growing and preparing fresh, healthy foods. They will be starting seeds in the hoop house and constructing bins for composting food waste from the school cafeteria. Through this garden, K-8th grade students will have the opportunity to participate in hands-on fresh food activities that they might not otherwise have the opportunity to experience.

CHECK OUT THE GALLERY FOR IMAGES & VIDEOS

Look Good, Do Good
With every contribution to our garden, donors will receive organic, ethical perks from PACT. Our socks, undies, and t-shirts are produced to high standards of sustainability, with the comfiest organic materials we can find. You'll be giving out of the goodness of your heart, and in return you'll get PACT goodies. It's a win-win situation.

story:
Short Summary

We are Daniel and Shellie Terry, from Sparks Nv.  We have been a part of Faces of Grace Outreach Ministry for the last 4 years.  We started as volunteers, but have been in charge of fund raising for the last 3 years!  We are dedicated to help people in need, the working poor and those who need a hand to get back on their feet in our community.  Faces of Grace will be hosting the 7th Annual Homeless Awareness & Prevention Day, here in Reno/Sparks.  On that day we will serve lunch, free groceries, free clothing, free hygiene supplies, free haircuts, as well as feature many community services to 3000-7000 people in need. 

What We Need & What You Get

To fund an event this size, we need $10,000.00.  This money is used for food and paper products for lunch; Drinks and snacks for the children; Generator fuel; Portable Restrooms and Hand Washing Stations; Fuel for transporting supplies, volunteers and guests; Park Fees; Liability Insurance; and other various supplies.  People who donate to this event will greatly impact the community.  For less than $3.00 a person, you can provide a day of hope and possibilities, fellowship and resources, as well as much needed sustaining every day supplies.  All preparation and execution of this event is 100% volunteer driven.  Any money donated goes directly to the outreach.

The Impact

People who attend this event often get their clothing for winter survival, a haircut for job searching and other important services.  We have several testimonies of guests who were on the streets, getting the boost they needed from attending Homeless Awareness & Prevention Day, and are now working and able to pay rent.  Those people return, year after year, now, as volunteers, and inspirations to others.

Other Ways You Can Help

We thank you in advance for your contribution.  For more information, please visit our website, www.facesofgracereno.org.

story:
Sunny’s Bar was hit hard by Hurricane Sandy, and the damage to the building requires significant resources to make repairs in the basement and get Sunny’s back up and open.

What We Need

Restoring an historic bar is no easy task. The work we need in the basement has already been surveyed and drawn.  As soon as we get the permit from the Dept. of Buildings, we'll start digging! We just need help to pay for the big bill.
 
What we have been able to get so far…
  • Pumping and Debris Removal
  • Concrete Footing
  • Boiler Replacement
  • Hot water heater replacement
  • New Boiler Room Slab
  • Sewer Cleaning
  • Full Electrical Replacement
  • New compressor
  • Engineers Reports and Drawings
  • Geotechnical Reports
  • Architectural Drawings and Expeditor Fees
  • Legal Fees
 
The big stuff we still need…
  • Needle Beam Supports
  • New Concrete Slab foundation
  • Reinforce walls
  • Removal of Walk-in Refrigerator
  • Helica Piles
  • Resurfacing of floors
  • Painting
  • Sump Pump
 
The Impact
About 100 years ago, Sunny’s was a home base to longshoremen working at the docks of Red Hook Brooklyn. Over time, Sunny’s became a bar, passed down through three generations of the Balzano family, landing in the hands of Antonio “Sunny” Balzano in the 1980s. Sunny’s maintains a home-like feel, so much so that Sunny’s is a place where a regular Joe and celebrities butt elbows at the bar on any given night.
 
Very few places are left in NYC that harken back to a nearly extinct era where artists and musicians can come together to share their work and create community.
 
With your support, Sunny's can open our doors again by the end of June, and Sunny himself will finally again be able to say, “Welcome Home, Kid!”

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Follow us on twitter and spread the word: @RH_SunnysBar

Share this campaign with your networks!

Come have a drink with us in July!

Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Who We Are

We're a group of current and former Bowie High School students, brought together by the impact Mr. McIntyre and Mrs. Maxwell had on each of our lives. We're from different classes, different years, and different backgrounds, but we're working as a team to plan an event that honors these two outstanding educators.

How Is This Event Going to Work?

On Sunday June 2, 2013 at 2:00pm, we will have a student-run surprise retirement ceremony for Mr. McIntyre and Mrs. Maxwell.  It's going to have two parts. We're going to begin with a ceremony in the Bowie Center for the Performing Arts - we'll recognize them for their careers, have speeches from their family members, watch tribute videos, and share many, many jokes.

After we're done in the BCPA, everyone will make the trek up the ramp to the Bowie High Cafeteria for an extended reception period. We'll have some light food options, a DJ to keep the mood upbeat, and plenty of time for everyone to mingle and catch up with former classmates. 

We're planning the entire event as a surprise, so make sure not to mention anything to either one of them! (That applies especially to you current BHS students!) We want them to feel our collective gratitude for their many years of dedicated, selfless service to education. 

Why Do We Need Money?

First and foremost, we want this even to be free and easy to attend. Your donations will help us accomplish that by covering facilities costs and other administrative expenses. 

Second, we want to get both of them a nice gift. Your donations will help facilitate the different options we're considering (and your suggestions for this are certainly welcome!)

Finally, we're seeking to make the event fun and allow for former classmates to reunite and catch up. Because of that, we're looking to provide an atmosphere at the post-event reception that is relaxed and friendly. This involves decorations, catering and personnel, and your donations will help make that dream a reality. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is $5160 (The $160 being the 4% fee for reaching our fundraising goals). With that $5000 budget, we'll be carefully examining the quotes we've gotten from different vendors to make the event as successful as possible. 

We've designed a system of perks that will allow you to show your gratitude and appreciation to Mr. McIntyre and Mrs. Maxwell in a variety of different ways. Please read through each of them and consider donating to help this event become a reality.

Even with all of that, we want to emphasize that the focus of the event is on two amazing educators. If we don't raise a dime through this page, we'll still all get together and celebrate the impact McIntyre and Maxwell have made on our lives. We're looking for donations to make this a community-wide celebration. 

The Impact

Bowie has many qualities of a small town, and the interconnectedness of Bowie High is certainly one of them. Mr. McIntyre and Mrs. Maxwell have devoted themselves to the enrichment of our city and our community through their dedication to every student that came into their classroom. 

Your donation will allow us to make certain they know, as they head into retirement, that they have enriched thousands upon thousands of lives. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, you can still help us make this a reality! 

Let us know if you have any connection to a local business that may be willing to advertize in our program or offer a donation. Many businesses in our area employ Bowie High graduates (or are even run by BHS grads), and we'd love to get as many of them as possible involved in this effort. 

Most of all, save the date for June 2nd! Tell your friends, former classmates, parents, and anyone else you think should know about this event. We want to pack the house and show our appreciation, and we need YOU - the most important part of this event - to make that happen.

story:
Our Story:

One cold winter day in a city playground, while our beloved children swirled around us, a single mom and a stay-at-home mom/part-time nanny started fantasizing about starting a business.  Giggling and dreaming and brainstorming, we allowed ourselves to visualize our fantasy as reality, and before you knew it we were checking out books at the library, pouring over financial spreadsheets, and preparing power point presentations.

What was our vision that so propelled us? Try to imagine walking down the Ithaca Commons on a cold and dark winter afternoon, and finding within a storefront a whole make-believe world. A child happily ascends a play structure and another one hops onto the slide. On the other side of the room behind a mural of the Commons, a little girl is tending store behind a play cash register, and another child fills a shopping cart. On a wooden loft above, two children prepare a meal at a play kitchen for some happy dolls in miniature high chairs. Behind the desk, a woman makes coffee and folds clothing for sale while a group of parents sit chatting with each other on two couches, their playful infants rolling around on a handmade quilt safely within reach.

This is Bloom, where budding minds go to play. It’s an indoor play spot for children aged 1-8, an educational and recreational center for families, and a retail clothing store specializing in American made, fair trade, organic, recycled, or handmade clothing and toys for children aged 2-8 and high quality, responsible clothing for women.

What We Need:

After nine months of very hard work, we have already realized half of our dream.  On Black Friday, we opened the doors of Bloom on the Ithaca Commons. Our retail store supplies the Ithaca community with sweatshop-free alternatives to mass produced clothing and gifts. From one of a kind handmade dolls in all color combinations to American made Ninja and Superhero t-shirts to organic cotton nursing bras, we've got Ithaca families all in a buzz about Bloom. However, nothing has created more excitement and anticipation than news of our upcoming play place, and thats where you come in. 

In order to create the play place of our dreams, we need another $6000. In order to realize this dream, we've had to quit our jobs and subsist on faith.  We don't have any more personal funds or bank financing we can call on. We could wait another few months while we try to raise the money from more traditional means, but its cold outside in Ithaca, and there's a foot of snow on the playgrounds! We think you need this play place now!

What's more, we want the financial security to be able to offer all the events and special offers that will make Bloom great and viable for all tiers of Ithaca Families, including:

Free Fridays after Five--come start the weekend with free play at Bloom!

Three Dollar Thursdays--discounted admission all day.

Monday Mugs--Free Coffee on Mondays!

The $6000 we are asking for will cover:

-Significant cosmetic renovations to our space. Although we are doing most of the work ourselves, we will be converting a century old storage room into safe kid space and updating the design of rooms that haven't been touched in decades!

-Construction of a play grocery store and a play restaurant, and purchase of toys and props.

-Construction of a loft "apartment" where children can play house.

-Comissioning of a mural by artist Grace Ritter to bring art and style to our space, as well as to set the "stage" for imaginative play.

-Purchases of American made furniture for our art space and parent lounge.

-Equipment for a self-serve coffee and healthy-snack bar for parents and children.

What You'll Get in Return:

In exchange for your contribution, you'll recieve the satisfaction knowing that you are helping achieve something for your community, that you are helping support imaginative play and involved parenting, American companies and jobs, and the revitalization of Downtown Ithaca. You'll also get lots of grattitude on our webpage, facebook wall, and on a permanent Thank You Wall we will paint next to our snack bar. And if you can contribute $25 or more, you can get hours of free play, VIP treatment, coupons, gift certificates, and even permanent discounts. And if you can donate $5000, we will set up a fund in your name to provide free play time to children who normally can't afford it.

The Impact:

We want to give Ithaca parents the opportunity to socialize and build community all the time, especially in the winter. We want to give Ithaca kids the opportunity to play with other children in a less structured environment than their school.  We want to provide a model of what imaginative and active play can look like without plastic imported toys that exploit workers overseas and poison our environments while cluttering our homes.
 
You too can be a part of this vision!

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that times are tough, and we also know firsthand the stress of unpaid bills and scarce pantries. If you aren't in a position to contribute this time around, you can still help us. Get the word out and make noise about our campaign. Call up wealthier relatives and tell them you need a place for playdates and they can help. Please share our campaign on facebook and twitter! And even more important, come visit us at Bloom and see what we have to offer.

Thank you all!

story:
Please help three crazy people start a small organic farm in Washington State.

 

Hi I’m Kat. It’s been a lifelong dream of mine to have a small organic farm that produces fresh organic fruits and vegetables, farm fresh organic eggs, and organic goat cheese. Somehow I’ve managed to convince both my husband David and our best friend Rook that this is a great idea.

David grew up on a horse ranch and knows all of the hard work and effort that goes into raising healthy happy animals. I love gardening as most of my extended family has gardened or farmed in one way or another throughout most of my growing up as well and I feel a deep connection to the earth and love to grow things. There is just something about the smell of damp earth and the feel of moist soil between your fingers. Our best friend Rook grew up raising cows and goats.

Together the three of us hope to start a very small sustainable organic farm  that will not only help to improve our overall health but give back to the community as well. By delivering organic farm fresh produce to local farmers markets, foodbanks and (hopefully) restaurants, we will be able to help people know just where there food is coming from and feel secure in the knowledge that it’s healthy, chemical, and GMO free.

Doing the research for this project has shown me that to start our adventure in agriculture it will run us somewhere between 90 and 100,000 dollars. We know that this is a large sum of money, but we are starting from scratch. Even if we don't reach our full goal any money we raise will go towards starting this venture.

There are several things that we will need to successfully launch our business.

 

  • We need to purchase the land. We are hoping to find roughly 10 to 15 acres of wooded or semi wooded land (for a reasonable price) with a good source of water somewhere in Washington State. 

 

  • We will need to build both our home and the milking and cheese manufacturing facilities. As well as the barn and paddock for the goats (and the llama) and the coop for the chickens. The dairy industry is the most highly regulated food industry in the U.S. so everything must be built to specific codes.

 

  • We will need to purchase equipment, livestock, and seeds. We can’t make goat cheese without the goats after all, or collect farm fresh eggs without chickens, and the last time I checked, you can’t grow fruits and veggies without seeds and trees, and it's difficult to build anything without the proper tools and supplies.

 

We are also thinking that some time down the road, (after all goat cheese making, and egg harvesting, and fruit and veggie growing is well under way) that we might add an apiary to our farm and try our hands at producing honey. But that would be a long way off in the future.

 

We truly feel that there needs to be more effort and enphisis on small scale organic farming in our country. To help keep things sustainable and lower the environmental impact we need to go back to our roots and start again at the begining. Your donations can help us show that we can produce good healthy food in a sustainable fashion without destroying the planet.

 

Even if you can't afford to make a donation, you can still help us by spreading the word and sharing the link to our fundraiser with as many people as you can. Indegog supports linking through facebook, Google +, and Twitter. If you feel as strongly about  improving life and sustainable farming as we do then please, make some noise.

 

Thank you.
story_txt:
Please help three crazy people start a small organic farm in Washington State.
 
Hi I’m Kat. It’s been a lifelong dream of mine to have a small organic farm that produces fresh organic fruits and vegetables, farm fresh organic eggs, and organic goat cheese. Somehow I’ve managed to convince both my husband David and our best friend Rook that this is a great idea.
David grew up on a horse ranch and knows all of the hard work and effort that goes into raising healthy happy animals. I love gardening as most of my extended family has gardened or farmed in one way or another throughout most of my growing up as well and I feel a deep connection to the earth and love to grow things. There is just something about the smell of damp earth and the feel of moist soil between your fingers. Our best friend Rook grew up raising cows and goats.
Together the three of us hope to start a very small sustainable organic farm  that will not only help to improve our overall health but give back to the community as well. By delivering organic farm fresh produce to local farmers markets, foodbanks and (hopefully) restaurants, we will be able to help people know just where there food is coming from and feel secure in the knowledge that it’s healthy, chemical, and GMO free.
Doing the research for this project has shown me that to start our adventure in agriculture it will run us somewhere between 90 and 100,000 dollars. We know that this is a large sum of money, but we are starting from scratch. Even if we don't reach our full goal any money we raise will go towards starting this venture.
There are several things that we will need to successfully launch our business.
 

We need to purchase the land. We are hoping to find roughly 10 to 15 acres of wooded or semi wooded land (for a reasonable price) with a good source of water somewhere in Washington State. 

 

We will need to build both our home and the milking and cheese manufacturing facilities. As well as the barn and paddock for the goats (and the llama) and the coop for the chickens. The dairy industry is the most highly regulated food industry in the U.S. so everything must be built to specific codes.

 

We will need to purchase equipment, livestock, and seeds. We can’t make goat cheese without the goats after all, or collect farm fresh eggs without chickens, and the last time I checked, you can’t grow fruits and veggies without seeds and trees, and it's difficult to build anything without the proper tools and supplies.

 
We are also thinking that some time down the road, (after all goat cheese making, and egg harvesting, and fruit and veggie growing is well under way) that we might add an apiary to our farm and try our hands at producing honey. But that would be a long way off in the future.
 
We truly feel that there needs to be more effort and enphisis on small scale organic farming in our country. To help keep things sustainable and lower the environmental impact we need to go back to our roots and start again at the begining. Your donations can help us show that we can produce good healthy food in a sustainable fashion without destroying the planet.
 
Even if you can't afford to make a donation, you can still help us by spreading the word and sharing the link to our fundraiser with as many people as you can. Indegog supports linking through facebook, Google +, and Twitter. If you feel as strongly about  improving life and sustainable farming as we do then please, make some noise.
 
Thank you.

story:
The Story

Hi, my name is Kristen and I have had my 1973 Mustang since I was a sophomore in high school and have always said SOMEDAY this car will be awesome. No one believed me because I was the girl with a busted, noisy car that broke down every other week. Since joining the Air Force, I have been deployed and assigned overseas several times and returned home only to spend all my money just to get the Stang back up and running again. The car has been continually neglected in my absence and also broken into twice ruining much of the interior.

 

 

The Solution 

Recently, I met the owner of Mustang Central, Allan Shepley. His shop has been featured in Mustang Monthly several times and he has been a part of many restoration projects on TV. Allan is just as excited about this project as I am, gave me a fair quote and would like to feature the car on his website throughout the rebuild!! I am finally in a position to stay put and look after my baby so the timing is perfect. Unfortunately, I have recently hit hard times financially due to helping out a friend in need.

The Goal

The goal amount needed to get the custom restore by Mustang Central is $60K. Because we will be working vigorously to offset the costs of the project while it is in progress, we are teaming up with local charities to donate any excess money collected. All funds will go towards making a lifelong dream come true and/or feeding the needy in the local area. If by chance, we do not meet our goal, the money raised will go to a single project for the car determined by the amount gathered.

This is close to what we're going for...fully restored to 100% mint condition but with a few differences.  All the chrome will be black including the wheels and instead of a deep gray the paint will be gloss black.  Which is why we called the project "Stealth Stallion".

The Dream

The opportunity to have this kind of top-notch, custom work is ONCE IN A LIFETIME! Having the project tracking is exciting and icing on the cake! If you are not able to donate but want to contribute to either cause then HELP SPREAD THE WORD!! Any and all help would be greatly appreciated and remember...

 

EVERY DOLLAR COUNTS!!

story:
Short Summary

I was born in rural village in western Kenya where I used kerosene lamps for studying. I was greatly affected and many of my friends dropped out of school. I decided to do something. In 2004 while I was 19 years old, i designed a simple solar lamp from mostly recycled materials which I call 'Mwangabora'.
 
Through my organization, Sustainable Development For All (www.sdfa-kenya.org), I have been distributing the solar lamps to poor rural families through women groups, and then helping the women set up income projects from the money they would have otherwise spent on kerosene. The solar lamps are greatly improving education for children and on my birthday on 11th March, I kindly ask you to help me provide this GIFT to 100 poor rural children in Kenya.

What We Need

We want to raise $2500 since each solar lamp costs us $25 to locally make. the lamps will be used by 100 families thsu directly impacting over 500 people.

The Impact

Each $25 will benefit at least 5 people and help at least 3 children study well. In addition, the mothers of all the children who will get the solar lamps will be trained in business skills and encouraged to save the money they would have otherwise spent on kerosene. They will then use the savings to start at least 1 income generating project after 4-6 months. The income project will not only provide them with a regular source of income but will also help them be self reliant and live happier lives.

Other Ways You Can Help

help us SPREAD the word. Email,tweet, facebook and share in any way with your friends, family or co-workers. You can also organize a small or big event to support our efforts.

story:
Hi Everyone, 

We are three sisters, Marla, Carissa, and Diana and though we live in New York, Singapore and Manila respectively, we have close ties to Cebu and Leyte, which were both severely impacted by Typhoon Haiyan. Last weekend, our father visited the devastated towns of Bogo and Bantayan Island in Northern Cebu to participate in relief efforts conducted by the University of Cebu and the highly-regarded Ramon Aboitiz Foundation  (http://rafi.org.ph or "RAFI").  He noted that while there is now a lot of food on the ground thanks to relief efforts led by international aid groups and the private sector, shelter continues to be a major issue. According to a recently released government report, more than 48,000 homes in 4 towns in Northern Cebu alone were damaged. 

Similarly, Keith Bradsher of the New York Times writes, "Shelter has not been a big priority for aid groups, which have focused on bringing in food, water and medical supplies first. The result is that almost all the tarpaulins here are scavenged from debris, sometimes with holes or rips. Virtually no tents have been put up". As a result, pneumonia and other respiratory infections have spread.  (http://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/23/world/asia/pneumonia-a-new-threat-to-storm-battered-philippines.html).

Together with  RAFI and its network of volunteers, we aim to raise money to provide temporary shelter kits to families from Northern Cebu, who were rendered homeless.  The shelter kits will give families an immediate place to sleep and allow them a measure of privacy in evacuation centers. Each shelter kit will cost 3,500 pesos (~$80) and will  consist of the following:

  • 3 x 5 meter tarpaulin sheet (to build a makeshift tent) and rope (10 meters)

  • Ground mat / sheet (2 x 4 meter)

  • Blanket / Mosquito Net

  • Cooking implements (pot and pan, utensils, kitchen knife)

  • Tools (e.g., hammer, saw, nails)

  • Plastic crate/ box (to hold all contents)

    Materials will be sourced locally to expedite procurement and distribution. Volunteers mobilized by RAFI will assist in the re-packing of the kits. Beneficiaries will be identified based on the results of the assessment to be conducted by RAFI/local government based on the family’s housing condition/needs and capability to obtain temporary shelter on their own. 

    If you cannot donate, I would appreciate it if you could help me get the word out. Every dollar helps put a roof over somebody's head!

    I will be providing updates and more photos (especially of the shelter kits) as this campaign progresses and if you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to email us at marladizon@yahoo.com.

    Thank you so much!

story:
Manhattan's oldest house needs your help! 

Any home needs some TLC, but a 248-year-old house needs some extra care! 

Need:

With your help we will raise $40,000 over the next 40 days to restore the exterior of the building. Not only would we like the Mansion to appear as welcoming as possible, but external restorations minimize the amount of interior restoration to be done later and help preserve the mansion for years of future use.


          


History: 

Perched on the second highest point of the isle of Manhattan, borough's oldest residence, the Morris-Jumel Mansion, serves as an important crossroads between the past in the present.

The Mansion boasts an impressive pedigree. It not only served as residence of two prominent New York families, but also as George Washington’s headquarters for a brief time during the Revolutionary War and, for a short while, as the home of founding father and third Vice President of the United States, Aaron Burr. The house was converted into a Museum in 1904 and has been in the service of the public ever since.



Creating History in the Present:

The Mansion and grounds offer more than a glimpse back in time, but serve as an important community resource, actively engaged in the lives of neighborhood members. The Mansion hosts many community events, not only for us, but also for many other local organizations, such as the Northern Manhattan Arts Alliance, Aaron Burr Association, Harlem Swing Society, the Historic House Trust Contemporary Art Partnership, and local businesses. The Mansion also provides many different types of educational programs, a free space for community performances and exhibitions, as well as a much needed green oasis in an otherwise heavily urban area. 

While programming and community involvement form the heart and soul of the museums mission, restoration of the premises is essential to keeping the museum an active community resource.

story:
Out of everything a person needs, freedom is the most important. And all people have a right to it. Unfortunately, people in the Kalamazoo area are targets of a heinous violation of freedom: human trafficking. We want to change that. 

Thanks to our generous funders, we have already reached our goal of $500 to file for 501(c)3 status! However, there is more work to be done: more community members to educate, more victims to find and support. Will you consider donating to KAHTC to help us do that?

The Kalamazoo Anti Human Trafficking Coalition, (KAHTC) is a community based volunteer organization created to fight the demand of human trafficking, raise the awareness of human trafficking and to uncover resources and assistance for human trafficking survivors all by collaborative efforts.  

KAHTC has a training committee, an awareness committee, a fundraising committee, an events committee, and an assistance committee.  All of these committees work together to educate the community on the reality of human trafficking in our surrounding communities and state.  Some of the groups we have been training include Kalamazoo Valley Community College nursing students, Kalamazoo County Juvenile Probation Officers, faith based organizations, Catholic Charities, area Kiwanis and Rotary organizations, Colleagues International FLEX students, just to name a few.  We have provided handout materials for people to study and use with the key indicators to recognize in a human trafficking victim and include the human trafficking hotline on all printed materials.  

Our hope in the future is to train the education, medical, and law enforcement professionals who would be the most likely to come in contact with human trafficking victims.  We have held three open community awareness events free to the public at various locations around Kalamazoo with expert presenters of human trafficking.  Some of those include the FBI, the Kalamazoo County Sheriff, the Michigan State Police, WAR International, the Michigan Attorney General’s office, Farmworkers Legal Services, National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, and the Michigan Human Trafficking Task Force.  

Through these efforts we have identified one human trafficking survivor and been able to connect her to the identified services she requires. We also had a mother come forward whose minor daughter is being lured online by an adult male to Florida and we have been able to put her in contact with the resources she needs.  

Thank you for your support! If you are unable to donate, you could help by visiting our web site at www.kahtc.org for volunteer and advocacy opportunities.

story:
Our Indiegogo Crowdfunding Campaign has now finished.  We are now offering a limited number of corporate sponsorship opportunities.  For more details check out blog www.mountain-minions.com, or drop us a line at mountain.minions@gmail.com.  Thanks.

 

The Project

Help us to improve education, transportation, communication, and job prospects in a remote Himalayan town through skiing!

We are Cara and Heather, and we are passionate about sharing our skill and love for snow travel with a community who could experience culturally and environmentally sustainable positive development as a result.

What does $10 mean to you?  For the students of Padum, it means the opportunity to learn skills that will improve communication, education, transportation, rescue, and job opportunities in their isolated community.

High up in the far-flung regions of the Indian Himalaya lies a small, isolated town called Padum. Padum is virtually inaccessible for eight months of the year, due to winter snowfall. As we found out first hand, this makes some aspects of life challenging.

Last February, we travelled 100km on foot up the frozen Zanskar River to volunteer our ski instructing services to the Zanskar Ski School, a small non-profit school set up to teach the children of this remote region how to ski – an incredibly valuable skill for people who are surrounded by some of the highest snow-covered peaks in the world.

However, we quickly realised that to truly advance in the art of skiing, the students need to visit an established ski area: there is a limit to how much skiing can be learnt on a 150m long homemade piste with no lift! 

During the long, chilly evenings a new dream was born: to bring a group of the most motivated ski students from Padum to the Indian ski resort of Gulmarg, where they will benefit from:

  • Advice from avalanche professionals
  • Two weeks of ski instruction
  • A gondola
  • Life skills with the potential to benefit the whole community

This is an opportunity that these children may never have again. Life in Padum continues as it has for centuries, and most of the children who stand to benefit from this project have never left their remote corner of the Himalaya before.

Why is this important?

The Zanskar Ski School, founded by British Geologist Ben and Zanskar's Outdoor Education Instructor Amin, aims:

“To provide communication, transportation, rescue and job opportunities for the people of the Zanskar Himalaya through skiing".

As you can see from their website, www.zanskarskischool.org, they do a fantastic job with limited resources.  Urgain, our host while visiting Padum and also the energetic in-situ manager of the Zanskar Ski School gives as much time as he can to skiing while juggling his family life and own business too.  However, without our help they may not be able to make their long-term dream a reality. We have an opportunity here to change winter-life in Padum for the better for generations to come.

Learning to ski effectively really can revolutionise communication links and transportation in this remote and isolated town. The five dedicated students that we bring from Padum will return home able to share their knowledge and experience with the other students. They will also be able to take more responsibility in the running of the ski school, ensuring its continuation. Their long-term prospects of finding a good job will be vastly improved, and in the short-term they may be able to travel to school more safely and easily.

For Cara and I, the deciding moment was when we asked Padma, the 13 year old daughter of our host in Padum, what she would think about the possibility of going to Gulmarg to ski. For a girl who has never left this remote corner of the Himalaya, and who has hiked for every ski turn she's ever made, this prospect was mind-blowing. Her face was a picture of incredulous excitement, and left us in no doubt whatsoever. We would do everything we could to bring these children to Gulmarg and share the joy and usefulness of skiing with them.

How Much?

To achieve our aim we need to raise $3500 Canadian. This will allow us to bring five students and their teacher from Padum to Gulmarg. Any contributions will only be used to bring the students. Cara and I will be volunteering our time, and funding our own travel to get to Gulmarg to instruct the students when they arrive.

The students journey from Padum to Gulmarg and back will involve:

  • Walking well over 100km on the frozen Zanskar River, with food costs of CA$500

  • Four flights over the mighty Himalaya at CA$1200

  • 300km of jeep travel on mountain roads, costing CA$500.

  • Contingency plans, hotel accommodation, and daily food costs at CA$1300

For most of these children, this will be their FIRST trip outside of the region of Ladakh. It offers opportunities not just to improve their lives through skiing, but also for personal development in other areas.

YOU CAN HELP US REACH OUR TARGET AND SHARE THE JOY AND BENEFITS OF SKIING WITH THESE CHILDREN AND THEIR WIDER COMMUNITY!

Just $500 is enough to give one student a set of wonderful new skills to share with their community.  We'd like to bring five students and their teacher.  If 350 people donate just $10 each, we will reach our target and make this dream a reality.  Any donation you can offer will be much appreciated and put to excellent use, and we are offering some great perks!

Please contribute via this page, and share our project with your friends!  Like us on Facebook, and follow our blog.  

If you are excited by our project, please help us to spread the word, make some noise about it, and keep an eye out for regular updates.

people of the Zanskar Himalaya through skiing".

you can see from their website, www.zanskarskischool.org,
they
do a fantastic job with limited resources.  Urgain, our host while visiting Padum and also the energetic in-situ manager of the Zanskar Ski School gives as much time as he can to skiing while juggling his family life and own business too.  However, without our help
they may not be able to make their long-term dream a reality.  We
have an opportunity here to change winter-life in Padum for the
better for generations to come.

Learning to ski effectively really
can revolutionise communication links and transportation in this
remote and isolated town.  The five dedicated students that we bring
from Padum will return home able to share their knowledge and
experience with the other students.  They will also be able to take
more responsibility in the running of the ski school, ensuring its
continuation.  Their long-term prospects of finding a good job will
be vastly improved, and in the short-term they may be able to travel to school more safely and easily.
For
Cara and I, the deciding moment was when we asked Padma, the 13 year
old daughter of our host in Padum, what she would think about the
possibility of going to Gulmarg to ski.  For a girl who has never
left this remote corner of the Himalaya, and who has hiked for every
ski turn she's ever made, this prospect was mind-blowing.  Her face
was a picture of incredulous excitement, and left us in no doubt
whatsoever.  We would do everything we could to bring these children
to Gulmarg and share the joy and usefulness of skiing with them.
How
Much?
To
achieve our aim we need to raise $3500 Canadian.  This will allow us
to bring five students and their teacher from Padum to Gulmarg.  Any
contributions will only
be used to bring the students.
Cara
and I will be volunteering our time, and funding our own travel
to get to Gulmarg to instruct the students when they arrive.
The
students journey from Padum to Gulmarg and back will involve:


Walking
	well over 100km
	on the frozen Zanskar River, with food costs of CA$500


Four
	flights
	over the mighty Himalaya at CA$1200


300km
	of jeep travel
	on mountain roads, costing CA$500. 
	


Contingency
	plans,
	hotel accommodation, and daily food costs at CA$1300


For
most of these children, this will be their FIRST trip outside of the
region of Ladakh.  It offers opportunities not just to improve their lives through skiing, but
also for personal development in other areas.
YOU
CAN HELP US REACH OUR TARGET AND SHARE THE JOY AND BENEFITS OF SKIING
WITH THESE CHILDREN AND THEIR WIDER COMMUNITY!
Just
$500 is enough to give one student a set of wonderful new skills to share with their community.  We'd like to bring five students and their teacher.  If 350 people donate just $10 each, we will reach our target and make this dream a reality.  Any donation you can
offer will be much appreciated and put to excellent use, and we are offering some great perks!
Please contribute via this page, and share our project with your friends!  Like us on Facebook, and follow our blog.  
If you are excited by our project, please help us to spread the word, make some noise about it, and keep an eye out for regular updates.

story:
About Us

Our names are Sarah and Emma, and we are 12 and 9 years old. We've decided that we needed to have our own business to make our own money.
 
Weren’t you sick of asking your Mom and Dad for money and them saying “No” all the time when you were younger?

Or do your chores first  - we love that one.

With a little help from our Dad, we decided to launch our own USDA (U.S. Department of Agriculture) Organic line of Lip Balms. Ya our Dad says organic is the best kind. We figured out he was right for once.


We got a sample batch from the manufacturing place in the United States and went door-door asking people to buy them.
 
It worked, we made money! Actually more money, our dad says, than teens at restaurants.
 

What We Need & What You Get

We need help to order a lot of all 5 flavours. We also have a Perk where you can give a kid a job. We'll send them enough of the flavours to make money and have enough to order more and keep making money for as long as they want.
 
We don't want to make money off other kids. You see the more kids that sell Liptacular lip balm the easier it is to buy from the manufacturing place.
 
Do you know how little paper route jobs there are now a days with the news on the internet?
 
And baby sitting jobs pffft... We don't mind now, we want people home to answer the door.
 

Our Ingredients & Why Liptacular Organic

 
Click our gallery page to see our ingredients list and to see why we need kids selling organic lip balm and why you should get one.
 
 
Made in the U.S.A
USDA Organic Certified
 

Know any KIDS who can't get even a paper route?

Kids and their parents looking to be apart of Liptacular at a later date shoud like us on facebook so they can get all the details when they become available.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Liking us on Facebook would be greatly appreciated.
 
Next time you kiss someone think about the chemicals and decide to go Liptacular Organic.
 
Thanks
Sarah & Emma

story:
Let the Road be Short 

My name is Chelsea, and I have a wonderful mom named Donna. In 2003 she began a new marriage with a man she found charming and intelligent. Over the past decade their relationship became toxic, causing my mother's health to deteriorate to the point where she is no longer able to work. Now, ten years later and in her fifties, she is taking the first terrifying steps toward divorce after being hospitalized when her body started shutting down due to consistent and prolonged stress.

Early in their marriage, they had moved to Ohio because he had received a job offer. We have no family in Ohio and she has now been cut off financially. She is relying on support from a women's shelter for goods such as toilet paper, and I am filled with sorrow that I am not financially stable enough to support her myself.

Our family is small and fractured; we do not have much money, and so are asking for assistance in helping our mom start over. Her goal is to relocate closer to one of her children, to focus on her healing, to continue practicing Buddhism, and altogether bring peace into her life where there has been turmoil for so long.

Any donation you make will enable my mom to buy food, pay the mortgage, and survive the day-to-day struggle of living until the divorce proceedings determine next steps.


If you are unable to contribute to our campaign, please consider 

  • spreading the word using Indiegogo's sharing tools;
  • educating yourself about domestic ptsd;
  • donating that old cell phone you don't use any more to a women's shelter; and
  •  keeping sweet thoughts of Donna in your mind and heart.


Thank you so much for time and attention.


September 14, 2013 Update

Before divorce proceedings can begin, the issue of my mom's and brother's protective orders need to be resolved. Their second court date was supposed to happen last week on the 12th, but her husband was able to push it out to October. This means that my mom will continue without any financial support for a lot longer than we had predicted. Additionally, she will need to find a divorce lawyer that can assist her, as her pro bono lawyer is only for the protective order trial (if you know of any generous Ohioan divorce lawyers, please send us their name!!).

Regardless of these setbacks, and even though the hyper-abundance of stress hormones continues to cause symptomatic outbreaks, my mom remains in good spirits. She asked me to communicate her disbelief and undying gratitude for the outpouring of support she has received. The act of being heard through this campaign has been very healing for her in surprising ways, so please continue sharing, even if you are unable to donate!

story:
Hi, I'm Trisha

      and I'm excited

                       to introduce

                                     my brand new business!


With Your Classroom Treasures  I hope to take a little of the pressure and stress off of Early Childhood Professionals while indulging in my love for shopping.

During my years as a Preschool Teacher I found it to be extremely satisfying to come away from a store, or a garage sale, with just the right item to enhance my classroom and to aid in learning.

I know from experience how much time and energy Teachers and Directors put into their rooms, and schools.

    Many of us have families of our own.

    Many of us use the bus for transportation.

    We might be able to stop in a store quickly, or set aside a portion of a day for        more serious shopping;

               but where is the time for searching through aisles and shelves;

                where is the time to get to that out of the way store;

                where is the time to hunt out garage sales;

                and where is the energy to see the possibilities in the unexpected.

This is the service I want to provide to the Early Childhood Community on Oahu by doing this type of shopping and taking my finds to them!

This is what you can help me accomplish!


What I need to get started:

On October 11, 2014 I have a great opportunity to introduce my business by being a vendor at the Early Childhood Conference.
 To make this happen I need funding for the following:
    rent for tables
    parking fees
    ad space in the program
    a printer
    flyers
    business cards
    packaging
    a website
    a cell phone
 and MOST IMPORTANTLY!
    toys and learning materials the teachers will want in their classroom.

I'm starting small because I want to get this business going and recognized. I truly believe Your Classroom Treasures will be welcome and embraced by the community.
I know there will be challenges and I will be seeking expertise from experienced entrepreneurs.
Even if I don't reach my full goal, I believe I will be enough interest to get me into the conference as a vendor allowing me to present myself and what I have to offer.

Even if you can't contribute at this time, please share my campaign with others. I appreciate it.
Thank you.
