story:
38 day old heirloom cherry tomato plant with its first fruit, potted in a 3 1/4" container. That's good pudding!

                        




Brio

bri·o 
[bree-oh; Italian bree-aw] 

noun

vigor; vivacity.


There is no question that many of us are concerned with our food, the type of seed that it is grown from, the methods used to produce it and where it is grown-preferably locally and without the use of chemical fertilizers and herbicides/pesticides; we want to know our farmer. And for an ever increasing number of us we want to have an even greater level of control by raising our own vegetable crops. 

One of the greatest challenges we all face when growing our own garden is improving our soil. Commercially available mixes can not enliven the soil like biologically active composts made with vital ingredients optimized for fertility.

Making compost locally is highly sustainable. It recycles local wastes to create a superior organic product compared to commercial mixes that are shipped in from great distance at the expense of both fuel and dollars.

I don't believe the current model works and, so, for the past several years I have worked on refining my method of composting large amounts of mostly horse manure along with food and garden waste, unwanted loose hays and other ingredients. The majority of this learning process has been by the building and frequent turning of very large piles by hand. Within the last 7 months I have had the opportunity to enjoy the use of some light machinery to increase the size and efficiency of the operation, but the use is borrowed and finite and it's really only available for personal production. 

I have also spent considerable time, effort and personal investment into learning the methodologies of vermicomposting, or using worms to transform waste material into rich, nutrient and biologically dense castings.

Right now I am ready to make a giant step forward in bringing to Northern New Mexico a source for locally produced, high quality compost, soil amendments and potting soil mixes and I need your help to do it!

What I guess this really comes down to for me is a firm belief that while we recycle many other items in our lives, it is equally important to recycle the nutrients in our lives. Without trying to sound like an idealist, we can not continue to take without giving. 

So here it goes. This is my humble plea to the world. I hate asking for anything and I will be honest, this is about the most terrifying thing I have ever done: Asking the world for contributions to get this vision off the ground. So thank you for making it this far down the page and please read on for further details. Your help is greatly appreciated.


The following is a general outline of the project model and products to be produced.

Additional and specific information is available for those requiring further detail upon request.

Note: all production methodologies are done to National Organic Program (NOP) standards and sourced inputs are OMRI labeled or approved for certified organic production.

                                                     Turning this




                                                         Into this


1- Compost: fueled by inputs of abundant and endless supplies of horse and other manures and virtually any waste material from anything that was ever alive. I am currently producing approximately 100 cubic yards per year. I anticipate increasing this number to 1,000-2,000 cubic yards per year minimum. Bear in mind that while this number may seem small compared to big market standards, Taos County has only 33,000 residents across 2,200 square miles.

                                                   To make this


2- Vermicompost: Worm, worms, worms! This is not some hair brained idea I picked up out of the back of Popular Mechanics, these little guys are a low carbon method of producing a nutrient dense and biologically rich soil conditioner, plant fertilizer and potting soil ingredient. Using pre-composted horse manure and food waste, the resulting product is a diverse blend of available nutrients which promote healthy plant growth. I currently manage approximately 30 pounds of composting worms producing several hundred pounds of vermicompost or worm castings per year. I would like to increase this amount by 10-20 times.


                      And this- deep, rich worm castings-as good as it gets!


3- Biochar: This is the big unknown for me, and really the only thing that is experimental. Essentially Biochar is an agricultural grade charcoal best known from its use in the creation of the Terra Prjeta Soils of the Amazon. It is known to increase the water retention abilities of soil and plays a role in soil nutrient exchange process as well as providing living quarters and a food source for soil fungi and biota. While charcoal production has historically had a nasty reputation of being a polluter, modern technology has virtually eliminated this. If I can not do this cleanly, I will not do it at all. The heat generated from the process can be used to continue the vermicomposting throughout the winter months as well as providing a heat source for winter greenhouse production. Inputs for this are any non-lumber woody debris that are currently disposed of for a fee at the county landfill. Here are a couple of links to wiki pages if you would like more information on this. 

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biochar

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terra_preta

                                            

4- Potting Soil and Raised Bed Mixes: I have spent considerable effort in experimenting and refining several potting soil mixes and a raised bed mix to create a locally produced product for the regional market to replace products shipped in from abroad utilizing personally produced and regionally sourced materials. Everything I make and everything I source is up to National Organic Program (NOP) standards with the goal of OMRI labeling the final destination. As good as these products are now, they will only get better with time. I am always learning and fine tuning. Im  always making it better.


                                               To accomplish something like this


3 months prior to this photo being taken, this plot of land was hard packed sand and gravel. With the addition of copious amounts of my compost, this is the result.


5-Jobs: Because we need them and I can't do this alone. I anticipate the creation of 3-6 full time, living wage or better jobs within 12 months.


This really is about having a positive impact on the world, reducing our needs on fossil fuels, promoting locally and regionally produced materials to aid the average gardener in their quest to provide a sustainable life for their own families, and to reuse the vast amount of organic matter and soil nutrients that are currently being wasted.

Nothing I am talking about here is really revolutionary or ground breaking. Systems like these are popping up all over the nation. For good reason. Help me bring this to Northern New Mexico.


What I Need & What You Get

Yes, that is a big number I'm trying to raise. Here is what I need to make this happen:

·  Dump truck-capable of carrying a minimum of 14 cubic yards of material. This is going to run in the $10,000-$15,000 range for a good used truck.

Something like this 

·  Flatbed trailer-to pull behind the dump truck- The one pictured here is about $2,800.  

·  Small tractor to load materials into the dump truck- This is the place i don't want to skimp. At the end of the day, this is going to be the workhorse that keeps things moving when big things invariably break down. This little guy is what is going to be loading the dump truck. Unfortunately most horse facilities in the area don't have their own tractor to load trucks with so I will do it for them - $18,000-$23,000. Something like this Kobuta but without the back hoe attachment.


·  Large front end loader-on the production grounds to turn the piles- Theres a really good deal on craigslist right now on a big articulating end loader with a 3 yard bucket to make short work and really make the job efficient. Can I live without this? Yeah, but I am all efficiency and the bucket on this machine moves about 9 times the amount of material per motion as the little orange one above. This one is listed at $17,500. 



·  Containers to haul restaurant waste- this can range anywhere from several hundred 5 gallon bucket with lids that restaurants and individuals can put food waste into for regular pick up, to standard 3 yard metal bins for larger consumers- A food grade bucket with a screw on lid is $20 retail. I can get them wholesale for $12. At 100 buckets- $1,200 

· Biochar kiln- Materials and welding labor- $4,300

· Worm stock- $160 shipped per ten pounds. 300 pounds- $4,800

· Continuous flow harvesting beds for vermicompost- 420 square feet- 4 beds @3'x35'-built on site- $4,500

· Temperature and Moisture Probes- $500

·  Material sifter, hopper, mixer and bagger- Its obscene how much these things cost out of a factory. I found some used for about $35,000 but that is not feasible for me. A custom made unit manufactured on-site- $6,000

· Wood chipper- A PTO driven NorTrak that can handle a 5 1/2" diameter branch, delivered- $2500. 

·  Fuel……..

·  Insurance- Im still working out the details of this with the insurance company. Last year the $1,000,000 in liability I carried on the farm ran $155/mo. Its likely going to double or more adding in the machinery to the premises. 

·  Initial purchase of non-produced materials for potting mix- Without getting into proprietary details about whats going in the mixes that I don't make on site- $11,488. This is enough material for 3,600/1.5 cubic foot bags of soil mixes, or 200 cubic yards.

·  Packaging- 5,000 bags- $2,600

·  Marketing- This is really a pretty moderate expense. Much of this will be sold direct at the farm as well as at the farmers market along side the farms spring seedlings and produce. Im budgeting $1,500 for marketing costs as well as for labeling on the packaging.

·  Rent/Location- $12,000 per year. This expense is actually covered off of income generated by the farms market garden and seedling/transplants sales. 

· And a very little bit of padding. 

If the goal is reached, Indiegogo takes a 4% cut leaving $96,000. If the goal is not reached, they take 9%……The total of items above except for fuel, insurance and rent comes in at about $88,000. This is not leaving much room for error on my part. Fortunately I am surrounded by a host of intelligent and successful business people to act as a sort of board of directors and to help me make sound decisions. 

I would actually love to raise a little more then my goal is set for. As much money as it seems like, at the end of the day, for a project of this scale, its not that much. I am also running a short campaign time. 

The season for growing is nearly upon us, my phone is ringing and I can not keep up with the demand! Let's get this thing going!

I am doing the flexible funding option so whatever I raise, regardless of whether I hit the goal or not will be put towards making portions of this project happen. If I do not  hit the goal what I do is really dependent on what I raise. The first thing I will do is purchase a small tractor and trailer, increase the carrying capacity on my truck and unload the material by hand. Beginning with composting, I will grow the other aspects one step at a time.  With a little more influx I will begin bagging soil blends. Next I will add in the biochar production and finally, the expansion of the vermicomposting.




PSSST……...

I have kept if fairly quite outside of town but some who know me may have picked up hints of what Ive been doing over the last several months. In short, I was given the opportunity to take over the fledgling Blossoms and Sprouts Farm located on the former Blossoms Organic Nursery property last July. Its been a ton of work but anyone that has any knowledge about agriculture and food production knows this. Its been countless hours without compensation but it is something that I absolutely love, growing food and helping others to do the same. I brought it up to the break even point by the end of the season but at this point everything is coming out of my pocket to keep it moving forward. Vish and Uma Miller, the property owners are 100% behind both the farm and this project. They have been more then gracious in working with me to keep moving forward. This is an incredible location and platform. Really, this is a world class location to create a model for sustainable, manageable, self sufficient agriculture. 

                              https://www.facebook.com/blossomsandsprouts



                                                       Mid summer market

I am excited to begin announcing that I have submitted the application for Certified Organic Certification for vegetable and herb seedlings and transplants through the state of New Mexico! This is an entirely out of pocket investment.



The Impact.

Remember, I am already doing this albeit on a very minor scale. I am producing about 100 cubic yards of compost and a few hundred pounds of worm castings a year. The worm casts fill my needs as does the majority of the compost. The excess compost I do offer to the public sells without issue or complaint as fast as I can load a yard into the back of my truck, 42/5 gallon buckets at a time. What I'm doing now is going to make it available to everyone in my region while recycling literally tons of organic material that will otherwise go to landfills or rot in a pile behind a barn.


$5 goes a long way- I have an incredible network of friends around the world.....spread this around.......PLEASE. Seriously, I want 20,000 people to pitch in 5 bucks….that is all it takes. We can do this.

If you dont have a few bucks to throw into the pot, please just copy and paste this into a message or update your status on facebook, tweet the link, whatever. GET THE WORD OUT! I need everyone's help to do this! Expect me to pester you :) The sooner I raise these funds the sooner I stop bugging everyone and get to work on this before the start of gardening season here.


Thank You!


OK, about the perks. 

1- Its going to take time to bring all of this together. Im hoping to have much available product ready for spring planting but the reality is, is that much may not be ready until well into the summer. This project is about looking forward, your patience and forward glance is appreciated. 

2-As much as I would love for my local community to enable me to do this without any outside contributions, I just don't see that being a possibility. I expect (hope) to receive many contributions from outside of the region. Due to the nature of the items being produced, shipment to out of area contributors is not feasible. Im quite happy to package up and ship your physical contribution to you so long as shipping fees are paid on your end. My plan is to combine all the outside contributions into increments of $1,000 and at local schools, nursing homes, homeless shelters etc, build raised bed gardens and plant vegetable seedlings in them. Does that seem reasonable?

3- Regular updates- I have created a page on Facebook to post updates and show the progress of what is happening. Updates will also be posted on the Blossoms & Sprouts Farm page…..please "like" us too! You deserve to know!

4- Education- I'm generous with what I know and share it readily. Do you or someone you know want to build something like this for your own community? Come and learn here!


NOTE TO REGIONAL LIVESTOCK OWNERS: I will be doing regular pickups of animal and agricultural waste free of charge. Your contributions to this project will ensure your days of trying to get rid of your manure piles are over.
story_txt:
38 day old heirloom cherry tomato plant with its first fruit, potted in a 3 1/4" container. That's good pudding!

                        








 

Brio
bri·o  [bree-oh; Italian bree-aw] 

 
 noun  
vigor; vivacity.

There is no question that many of us are concerned with our food, the type of seed that it is grown from, the methods used to produce it and where it is grown-preferably locally and without the use of chemical fertilizers and herbicides/pesticides; we want to know our farmer. And for an ever increasing number of us we want to have an even greater level of control by raising our own vegetable crops. 
One of the greatest challenges we all face when growing our own garden is improving our soil. Commercially available mixes can not enliven the soil like biologically active composts made with vital ingredients optimized for fertility.
Making compost locally is highly sustainable. It recycles local wastes to create a superior organic product compared to commercial mixes that are shipped in from great distance at the expense of both fuel and dollars.
I don't believe the current model works and, so, for the past several years I have worked on refining my method of composting large amounts of mostly horse manure along with food and garden waste, unwanted loose hays and other ingredients. The majority of this learning process has been by the building and frequent turning of very large piles by hand. Within the last 7 months I have had the opportunity to enjoy the use of some light machinery to increase the size and efficiency of the operation, but the use is borrowed and finite and it's really only available for personal production. 
I have also spent considerable time, effort and personal investment into learning the methodologies of vermicomposting, or using worms to transform waste material into rich, nutrient and biologically dense castings.
Right now I am ready to make a giant step forward in bringing to Northern New Mexico a source for locally produced, high quality compost, soil amendments and potting soil mixes and I need your help to do it!
What I guess this really comes down to for me is a firm belief that while we recycle many other items in our lives, it is equally important to recycle the nutrients in our lives. Without trying to sound like an idealist, we can not continue to take without giving. 
So here it goes. This is my humble plea to the world. I hate asking for anything and I will be honest, this is about the most terrifying thing I have ever done: Asking the world for contributions to get this vision off the ground. So thank you for making it this far down the page and please read on for further details. Your help is greatly appreciated.

The following is a general outline of the project model and products to be produced.
Additional and specific information is available for those requiring further detail upon request.
Note: all production methodologies are done to National Organic Program (NOP) standards and sourced inputs are OMRI labeled or approved for certified organic production.
                                                     Turning this



                                                         Into this

1- Compost: fueled by inputs of abundant and endless supplies of horse and other manures and virtually any waste material from anything that was ever alive. I am currently producing approximately 100 cubic yards per year. I anticipate increasing this number to 1,000-2,000 cubic yards per year minimum. Bear in mind that while this number may seem small compared to big market standards, Taos County has only 33,000 residents across 2,200 square miles.
                                                   To make this



2- Vermicompost: Worm, worms, worms! This is not some hair brained idea I picked up out of the back of Popular Mechanics, these little guys are a low carbon method of producing a nutrient dense and biologically rich soil conditioner, plant fertilizer and potting soil ingredient. Using pre-composted horse manure and food waste, the resulting product is a diverse blend of available nutrients which promote healthy plant growth. I currently manage approximately 30 pounds of composting worms producing several hundred pounds of vermicompost or worm castings per year. I would like to increase this amount by 10-20 times.

                      And this- deep, rich worm castings-as good as it gets!

3- Biochar: This is the big unknown for me, and really the only thing that is experimental. Essentially Biochar is an agricultural grade charcoal best known from its use in the creation of the Terra Prjeta Soils of the Amazon. It is known to increase the water retention abilities of soil and plays a role in soil nutrient exchange process as well as providing living quarters and a food source for soil fungi and biota. While charcoal production has historically had a nasty reputation of being a polluter, modern technology has virtually eliminated this. If I can not do this cleanly, I will not do it at all. The heat generated from the process can be used to continue the vermicomposting throughout the winter months as well as providing a heat source for winter greenhouse production. Inputs for this are any non-lumber woody debris that are currently disposed of for a fee at the county landfill. Here are a couple of links to wiki pages if you would like more information on this. 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biochar
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terra_preta
                                            
4- Potting Soil and Raised Bed Mixes: I have spent considerable effort in experimenting and refining several potting soil mixes and a raised bed mix to create a locally produced product for the regional market to replace products shipped in from abroad utilizing personally produced and regionally sourced materials. Everything I make and everything I source is up to National Organic Program (NOP) standards with the goal of OMRI labeling the final destination. As good as these products are now, they will only get better with time. I am always learning and fine tuning. Im  always making it better.

                                               To accomplish something like this

3 months prior to this photo being taken, this plot of land was hard packed sand and gravel. With the addition of copious amounts of my compost, this is the result.

5-Jobs: Because we need them and I can't do this alone. I anticipate the creation of 3-6 full time, living wage or better jobs within 12 months.

This really is about having a positive impact on the world, reducing our needs on fossil fuels, promoting locally and regionally produced materials to aid the average gardener in their quest to provide a sustainable life for their own families, and to reuse the vast amount of organic matter and soil nutrients that are currently being wasted.
Nothing I am talking about here is really revolutionary or ground breaking. Systems like these are popping up all over the nation. For good reason. Help me bring this to Northern New Mexico.

What I Need & What You Get
Yes, that is a big number
I'm trying to raise. Here is what I need to make this happen:
· 
Dump truck-capable of
carrying a minimum of 14 cubic yards of material. This is going to run in the $10,000-$15,000 range for a good used truck.Something like this · 
Flatbed trailer-to
pull behind the dump truck- The one pictured here is about $2,800.  

· 
Small tractor to load
materials into the dump truck- This is the place i don't want to skimp. At the end of the day, this is going to be the workhorse that keeps things moving when big things invariably break down. This little guy is what is going to be loading the dump truck. Unfortunately most horse facilities in the area don't have their own tractor to load trucks with so I will do it for them - $18,000-$23,000. Something like this Kobuta but without the back hoe attachment.

· 
Large front end loader-on the production grounds to turn the piles- Theres a really good deal on craigslist right now on a big articulating end loader with a 3 yard bucket to make short work and really make the job efficient. Can I live without this? Yeah, but I am all efficiency and the bucket on this machine moves about 9 times the amount of material per motion as the little orange one above. This one is listed at $17,500. 

·  Containers
to haul restaurant waste- this can range anywhere from several hundred 5 gallon bucket with lids that restaurants and individuals can put food waste into for regular pick up, to standard 3 yard metal bins for larger consumers- A food grade bucket with a screw on lid is $20 retail. I can get them wholesale for $12. At 100 buckets- $1,200 

· Biochar kiln- Materials and welding labor- $4,300

· Worm stock- $160 shipped per ten pounds. 300 pounds- $4,800· Continuous flow harvesting beds for vermicompost- 420 square feet- 4 beds @3'x35'-built on site- $4,500· Temperature and
Moisture Probes- $500

· 
Material sifter,
hopper, mixer and bagger- Its obscene how much these things cost out of a factory. I found some used for about $35,000 but that is not feasible for me. A custom made unit manufactured on-site- $6,000· Wood chipper- A PTO driven NorTrak that can handle a 5 1/2" diameter branch, delivered- $2500. 

· 
Fuel……..

· 
Insurance- Im still working out the details of this with the insurance company. Last year the $1,000,000 in liability I carried on the farm ran $155/mo. Its likely going to double or more adding in the machinery to the premises. 

· 
Initial purchase of
non-produced materials for potting mix- Without getting into proprietary details about whats going in the mixes that I don't make on site- $11,488. This is enough material for 3,600/1.5 cubic foot bags of soil mixes, or 200 cubic yards.

· 
Packaging- 5,000 bags- $2,600
· 
Marketing- This is really a pretty moderate expense. Much of this will be sold direct at the farm as well as at the farmers market along side the farms spring seedlings and produce. Im budgeting $1,500 for marketing costs as well as for labeling on the packaging.

· 
Rent/Location- $12,000 per year. This expense is actually covered off of income generated by the farms market garden and seedling/transplants sales. · And a very little bit of padding. If the goal is reached, Indiegogo takes a 4% cut leaving $96,000. If the goal is not reached, they take 9%……The total of items above except for fuel, insurance and rent comes in at about $88,000. This is not leaving much room for error on my part. Fortunately I am surrounded by a host of intelligent and successful business people to act as a sort of board of directors and to help me make sound decisions. I would actually love to raise a little more then my goal is set for. As much money as it seems like, at the end of the day, for a project of this scale, its not that much. I am also running a short campaign time. The season for growing is nearly upon us, my phone is ringing and I can not keep up with the demand! Let's get this thing going!I am doing the flexible funding option so whatever I raise, regardless of whether I hit the goal or not will be put towards making portions of this project happen. If I do not  hit the goal what I do is really dependent on what I raise. The first thing I will do is purchase a small tractor and trailer, increase the carrying capacity on my truck and unload the material by hand. Beginning with composting, I will grow the other aspects one step at a time.  With a little more influx I will begin bagging soil blends. Next I will add in the biochar production and finally, the expansion of the vermicomposting.PSSST……...I have kept if fairly quite outside of town but some who know me may have picked up hints of what Ive been doing over the last several months. In short, I was given the opportunity to take over the fledgling Blossoms and Sprouts Farm located on the former Blossoms Organic Nursery property last July. Its been a ton of work but anyone that has any knowledge about agriculture and food production knows this. Its been countless hours without compensation but it is something that I absolutely love, growing food and helping others to do the same. I brought it up to the break even point by the end of the season but at this point everything is coming out of my pocket to keep it moving forward. Vish and Uma Miller, the property owners are 100% behind both the farm and this project. They have been more then gracious in working with me to keep moving forward. This is an incredible location and platform. Really, this is a world class location to create a model for sustainable, manageable, self sufficient agriculture.                               https://www.facebook.com/blossomsandsprouts                                                       Mid summer marketI am excited to begin announcing that I have submitted the application for Certified Organic Certification for vegetable and herb seedlings and transplants through the state of New Mexico! This is an entirely out of pocket investment.
The Impact.Remember, I am already doing this albeit on a very minor scale. I am producing about 100 cubic yards of compost and a few hundred pounds of worm castings a year. The worm casts fill my needs as does the majority of the compost. The excess compost I do offer to the public sells without issue or complaint as fast as I can load a yard into the back of my truck, 42/5 gallon buckets at a time. What I'm doing now is going to make it available to everyone in my region while recycling literally tons of organic material that will otherwise go to landfills or rot in a pile behind a barn.$5 goes a long way- I have an incredible network of friends around the world.....spread this around.......PLEASE. Seriously, I want 20,000 people to pitch in 5 bucks….that is all it takes. We can do this.If you dont have a few bucks to throw into the pot, please just copy and paste this into a message or update your status on facebook, tweet the link, whatever. GET THE WORD OUT! I need everyone's help to do this! Expect me to pester you :) The sooner I raise these funds the sooner I stop bugging everyone and get to work on this before the start of gardening season here.Thank You!OK, about the perks. 1- Its going to take time to bring all of this together. Im hoping to have much available product ready for spring planting but the reality is, is that much may not be ready until well into the summer. This project is about looking forward, your patience and forward glance is appreciated. 2-As much as I would love for my local community to enable me to do this without any outside contributions, I just don't see that being a possibility. I expect (hope) to receive many contributions from outside of the region. Due to the nature of the items being produced, shipment to out of area contributors is not feasible. Im quite happy to package up and ship your physical contribution to you so long as shipping fees are paid on your end. My plan is to combine all the outside contributions into increments of $1,000 and at local schools, nursing homes, homeless shelters etc, build raised bed gardens and plant vegetable seedlings in them. Does that seem reasonable?3- Regular updates- I have created a page on Facebook to post updates and show the progress of what is happening. Updates will also be posted on the Blossoms & Sprouts Farm page…..please "like" us too! You deserve to know!4- Education- I'm generous with what I know and share it readily. Do you or someone you know want to build something like this for your own community? Come and learn here!NOTE TO REGIONAL LIVESTOCK OWNERS: I will be doing regular pickups of animal and agricultural waste free of charge. Your contributions to this project will ensure your days of trying to get rid of your manure piles are over.

story:
Short Summary

Are you watching what you put in your body but paying little or no attention to what you're putting on it? Doc's Skincare develops and produces unique, all-natural personal care products that meet the demanding requirements of high-performance athletes - cyclists, runners, and triathletes - as well as recreational sports and fitness enthusiasts. The company is focused on production of effective products that use a minimum of 95% natural ingredients and is poised as the leader in this niche market.  Doc's Skin Care is everything you need and nothing you don't.


What We Need & What You Get

We've established ourselves in this unique market with a profitable business model and product delivery system.  We are anticipating that 2014 will be a breakout year.  In order to meet this expectation, we need to initiate a targeted smart advertising campaign. We are in discussions with a celebrity athlete (remains confidential until finalized) to become our company spokesperson.

Help us fund the start of this advertising campaign:

  • $56,000 - athlete acquisition and advertising development
  • $44,000 - overall company advertising
  • $10,000 - branding strategy
  • $10,000 - trade show set-up

The Impact

By helping us raise only $35,000 of the total $120,000 total needed in the 2014 advertising campaign, you'll give us the necessary "seed" money to launch things in the right direction for 2014.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
What is Nutriunt? 

Nutriunt will be a local organic exotic aquaponic farm that offers exotic variety. Instead of traveling miles to get to your plate, it will be possible to have it travel from farm to fork. We couldn't be more proud in that we will be providing produce and fish to our community that will be grown using the efficiency of aquaponics, free from pesticides, synthetic fertilizers, GMO’s, and growth hormones. Nutriunt will always live by the definition of what it truly means to be organic and pure. 


How we will accomplish this? 

What is going to make all of this possible is the amazing ability of aquaponics and growing in a lovely greenhouse. Aquaponics is hydroponics married with aquaculture, a sustainable ecosystem. The fish waste is converted into plant food on a biological level. In turn the plants filter the nitrates from the water to foster, while neutralizing and purifying the water for the fish. This means the crop will have an unaltered steady stream of natural organic nutrients.


Aquaponics:




Nutriunt's Goal  

The Nutriunt team is trying to raise $7,000, but we are looking to shatter that with your support! Every dollar is going to be used for everything from the seed to the structure! Even if we don't meet our funding goal, we are going to make due with what we are able to raise. If we raise more than our target goal we will be able to expand the design of the growing system to offer even more organic heirloom varieties. With the current system design we will be able to produce a combination of over 1,000 heads of lettuce, leafy greens, bunches of basil, and a variety of fruits and vegetables monthly.


Where your money is going?

  • Greenhouse
  • Organic seed
  • Tilapia 
  • Grow bed troughs
  • PVC plumbing
  • Fish tank
  • Sumps and pumps
  • Shale rock
  • Growing medium
  • Basic shop tools 
  • Your continuous support will allow Nutriunt to afford a delivery van! If you help us shatter our funding goal we will be able to deliver and make a presence at farmers markets.


What you get!

What you will receive is determined by your perk selection. Your perk will include a combination of leafy greens, lettuce, and herbs. Nutriunt merchandise is included in most of the perks.


Live Produce

Another amazing feat that will be able to be accomplished is selling live produce! Aquaponics makes it possible because of the accessibility of the crop and the versatility of mother nature. 


The Goods  

Even before the plants begin to grow, we take care in where we attain our seed. The seeds won't even make it to our grow beds unless they come from an organic source or a trustful association. Below are just a few of the crops that we will begin to offer upon opening:





Lettuce/Leafy Greens 



Red Romaine

Origin: Rome

Facts: Romaine lettuce was served on the tables of Persian kings and praised for it's medicinal values.

Description: Red Romaine Lettuce has long crunchy spoon shaped leaves that start green and fade to profuse purple/red.

Nutrition: A great source of vitamins A, C, high in vitamin K, dietary fiber, folate, molybdenum, fiber, manganese, potassium, biotin, vitamin b1, copper, iron, calcium, and magnesium.

Use: Red Romaine is just as good as its cousin, but it will add zest and some color to a flavorful salad. Red Romaine is often used in Caesar salads for its crunch and color.




Merlot Lettuce

Origin: Netherlands

Facts: Merlot has one of the highest contents of antioxidants when it comes to leafy produce. Also known as “Galactic”, this lettuce is so exquisite! Reputed to be the darkest red lettuce in existence. 

Description: Is a striking deep dark red color and a bit of green at the base. Has a sweet, delicate, and crispy taste. Stays sweet at all sizes.

Nutrition: Good source of Protein, Calcium, Magnesium and Phosphorus, Dietary Fiber, Vitamin A, Vitamin C, Vitamin K, Thiamin, Riboflavin, Vitamin B6, Folate, Iron, Potassium and Manganese.

Use: Is great paired with any other greens. Can also be used as a beautiful garnish or enjoyed on it's own.




Bronze Beauty Lettuce

Origin: Chicago, USA

Facts: Recognized as the finest, most colorful and most delicious leaf lettuce. Also known as Bronze Arrowhead. All-America Award winner for 1947, the year it was introduced by Germania Seed Company.

Description: Hands down one of the best lettuces that I have had the pleasure of tasting. Is a leaf type lettuce. Sweet nutty leaves are blushed with medium bronze, mainly around the wavy leaf margins.

Nutrition: Being a leaf lettuce it is a good source of Protein, Calcium, Magnesium and Phosphorus, and a very good source of Dietary Fiber, Vitamin A, Vitamin C, Vitamin K, Thiamin, Riboflavin, Vitamin B6, Folate, Iron, Potassium and Manganese.

Use: The tender crisp leaves can be added to any mixed green salad and would be a great addition to any sandwich.




Lollo Rossa Lettuce

Origin: Italy

Facts: It was discovered that Lollo Rossa has 100 times more antioxidants than common lettuce in 1999 by scientists at the University of Glasgow.  Lollo Rossa Lettuce contains the antioxidant quercetin, which is believed to help prevent asthma and allergies by acting as a natural antihistamine.

Description: It is known to be used as a supplemental lettuce to mix with other lettuces of varying textures and flavor. It has compact rosette fan shaped leaves that are violet in color with a pale green base.

Nutrition: Loose-leaf lettuces such as Lollo Rossa provide vitamins A and C, folate, and iron.

Use: Can be blended with other greens in a salad, garnish soups, bed for presentations, and used on sandwiches.




Flashy Butter Gem Lettuce

Origin: Oregon, USA

Facts: Flashy butter gem lettuce is a romaine type lettuce. Can be harvested mini or at full maturity with no sacrifice in flavor. Grows in a short thick bunch. Frank Morton original.

Description: This lettuce has a soft buttery texture and dappled in crimson. 

Nutrition: Good source for Vitamins, A, C, K, and folate, iron, and dietary fiber.

Use: Gourmet quality lettuce for any salad mix.





Herbs/Basil 



Blue Spice

Orgin: Africa

Facts: Deep fragrance with spicy vanilla overtones and a hint of lemon.

Description: Has a lovely inflorescence with light purple flowers set on deep purple bracts. 

Nutrition: Like most other basil, blue spice is rich in Vitamin A, Vitamin C, Vitamin K, Vitamin B6, Folate, Calcium, Iron, Magnesium, Phosphorus, Potassium, Zinc, Copper and Manganese.

Use: Prime for fruit salads. Can also be used in poultry dishes, marinades, dressings, and beverages. 




Dark Purple Opal: 

Origin: France

Facts: Opal basil was first discovered in 1830 by George Bentham, a British botanist. 

Description: Is a sweet basil cultivar. Opal basil has egged shaped leaves that are glossy, toothed at the edge, and are dark purple in color.

Nutrition: Vitamin A, Vitamin C, Vitamin K, Vitamin B6, Folate, Calcium, Iron, Magnesium, Phosphorus, Potassium, Zinc, Copper and Manganese.

Use: Is commonly used in Thai, Vietnamese, and Italian foods. Opal basil can be used to make a purple pesto and the leaves can be used to make an aromatic herbed vinegar or oils.




Cinnamon:

Origin: Southeast Asia

Facts: Is known as Mexican spice basil. The seeds of cinnamon basil are used as a thickening agent but don't share the aromatic properties of the leaves.

Description: Is smaller than sweet basil and has narrower leaves, Is know for it's darker color, cinnamon like taste, and intense aroma.

Nutrition: Vitamin A, Vitamin C, Vitamin K, Vitamin B6, Folate, Calcium, Iron, Magnesium, Phosphorus, Potassium, Zinc, Copper and Manganese.

Use: Goes great with fruit and is delicious in Asian, Indian, and Italian dishes. Is also a savory element to raw dishes, soups, and hot drinks.




Ararat

Origin: India 

Facts: The flowers are edible. The licoriceanise fragrance is crisp and wins taste tests among purple basil.

Description: Has bi-color leaves. Purple and green mingled together. Has an unusually intense aroma and flavor. T

Nutrition: Vitamin A, Vitamin C, Vitamin K, Vitamin B6, Folate, Calcium, Iron, Magnesium, Phosphorus, Potassium, Zinc, Copper and Manganese.

Use: Can be used in salads, on a sandwich, herbal vinegar, sauces, soups, and as a beautiful garnish.





Fruit



Kiwano - African Horned Cucumber Melon

Origin: Africa

Facts: The horned melon is one of the few melons that actually resembles a cucumber more than a melon. The kiwano is primarily cultivated in New Zealand, where it was introduced in the 1930's.

Description: The kiwano has a bright deep orange skin at maturity. The flesh is a lime green color resembling Jell-O. It produces spikes across it's spattered orange and yellow skin. The melon has a sweet tart tropical banana-lime taste to it. 

Nutrition: The Horned Melon consists of 90% water and rich in Vitamin C. It is also a good source of iron and potassium. 

Use: Can be used to make a seed free juice cocktail. Is fantastic when added to smoothies. Goes great in fruit salads and sauces. The hollowed shell is perfect for a unique serving dish.




Green Zebra Tomato:

Origin: Washington, USA

Facts: A favorite tomato of many high class chefs and restaurateurs. 

Description: Flesh is bright green and has a rich sweet tangy taste. Has green skin blushed with yellow-lime stripes. 

Nutrition: Is a great source of lycopene and has cancer fighting capacity. High in Vitamin C and Vitamin A.

Use: Tastes great sliced fresh in salads. Can also be eaten like an apple right off the vine. Is also known to make a delicious green ketchup.





Blue Berries Tomato:

Origin: California, USA

Facts: Small cherry variety from Brad Gates, Wild Boar Farms. 

Description: Unripe, the fruit are an amethyst purple. When mature turn a deep red where fruit was shaded and a dark purple, almost black, where it received intense sunlight.  Intense fruity flavor and very sweet. 

Nutrition: Very rich in anthocyanins. High in Vitamin C and A. Also a great source for potassium, iron, and lycopene.

Use: Can be eaten like grapes, sliced in a fruit salad, or added whole. Can also be blended into a smoothie. Would also be great when added to sweet sauces and spreads. 




Yellow Pear Tomato:

Origin: South America

Facts: Is a member of the cherry tomato family. 

Description: Very sweet. Resembles the shape of a pear. 

Nutrition: High in Vitamin C. Great source for iron and lycopene.  

Use: Great for fresh eating. Great choice for tomato preserves. Adds great taste and color to any salad. Can also be a sun dried variety. 




Copia Tomato:

Origin: California, USA

Facts: They were named in honor of Copia, the American center for Food, Wine, and the Arts, in Napa California. 

Description: Larger tomato variety. Has golden yellow and red vertical stripes when fully ripe. The flesh is a combination of yellow and red swirled together, and is sweet and juicy.  

Nutrition: As other tomatoes, the copia is a great source of lycopene. High in Vitamin A and C. Also provides iron and potassium.

Use: Stunning when sliced with dark opal basil and fresh mozzarella. Can be diced and added to salads. Would also add some fire to a sandwich. 





Tilapia  


Origin: Native to Africa ad Israel 

Facts: Is commercial known as the "mango fish" and can also be found in Egypt.

Description: These are the locomotives of our ecosystem! The nile tilapia has distinctive vertical stripes extending as far down the body as the caudal fin with variable coloration.

Nutrition: The tilapia is a lean fish. It is high in protein and iron.

Use: Will also be available for purchase at maturity which takes 8-12 mos, which is about 12" weighing in at 1.5 pounds. Is very popular in the Thai cuisine and is known as "pomegranate" or "ruby" fish. It is genreally battered and pan fried whole, or grilled whole.




The Impact!

Pollution & Air Quality: Being able to yield more crop per acre compared to conventional farming, we will be able to meet a demand in the city center while having a near zero carbon foot print. Nutriunt will not be using any expensive equipment to harvest our all natural crop. By purchasing from local farmers you will also avoid adding exhaust to our atmosphere because there will be merely no gap between the farm and your door step. They say our food currently travels hundreds of miles just to get to our dinner plate. Shopping local has shown so much success and is beneficial to society and our communities in the long run.

Water: Aquaponics uses a fraction of the water that conventional farming uses and yields 8 times as much food making it possible to conserve thousands of gallons a year. Conventional farming also uses 70% of our current fresh water. Herbicides and pesticides that are applied to the plants wash out into our rivers and oceans, creating dead zones where aquatic life is nonexistent. 

Community: As local farms grow new jobs become available in our local economy! By dramatically reducing the financial burden and reliance on fossil fuel based transport, chemical inputs, and refrigeration, more funding can stay in local urban economies where food is produced. Things become more personable when you shop local. The opportunity to meet your farmers and visit the place your crops are cultivated becomes feasible and never cumbersome.

Health: Even though they say that the pesticides used are “organic” on organic crops, doesn't mean it is in any way shape or form harmless. Another thing that is disheartening is that most of the "organic" food that we eat to avoid the "junk" companies, is owned by the junk companies! Some of the most harmful things on earth are invisible to the naked eye. Over 300,000 farm workers get sick every year because of the use of pesticides. Based on studies conducted by a multi-university research team in Toronto concludes that "people should reduce their exposure to pesticides because of links to serious illnesses". Results of this study found consistent evidence of serious health risks such as cancer, nervous system diseases and reproductive problems in people exposed to pesticides…through home and garden exposure. 

Environment: Chemical fertilizers destroy the properties of soil rendering it incapable of supporting plant life. By supporting Nutriunt, you will also aid in cutting back on deforestation. You heard that right! Conventional farming at this present time is the number one contributor to deforestation. We all know that our trees are essential in battling poor air quality. Researchers claim that we farm a landmass the size of South America. Farming indoors also eliminates the need to rely on fossil fuels for seeding, fertilizing, weeding, harvesting, and plowing! It will also give us the ability to avoid pests which prevents us from using any excessive harmful chemicals at all. Not adding or bringing any other harmful substances to the city.


Other Ways You Can Help 

It you are unable to contribute is no problem at all. The fact that you took the time out of your day to check out the Nutriunt funding campaign is greatly appreciated. A way that you can still help us succeed if you cannot contribute is using our links and sharing our campaign with your friends and family! Thanks again for taking the time. 


Frequently Asked Questions:


  • Does aquaponic produce taste different than soil? In my honest opinion, no. I have tasted aquaponic lettuce and tomatoes side by side. I was unable to tell which source either one of them came from. At times aquaponic produce seemed to be more colorful and tasty. 


  • Can we get e coli and salmonella from aquaponics? The simple fact that fish aren't warm blooded animals makes it impossible to contract any kind of bacteria in that form or even leach it in our system. If we were to introduce any kind of warm blooded animal excrement or fertilizers into our system, then there would be many risks taken going that route.


  • Will you grow other things in the future? This is always a favorite question. We couldn't be more ecstatic to offer different varieties of produce as we grow in the community. That is one of our ultimate goals.


  • Are indoor crops healthier? Yes, they can be because you aren't forced to use any pesticides, herbicides, or any kind of chemicals to fend off pests and enrich the soil. At the same time we are able to closely monitor the crop environment.


  • How does aquaponics use less water? By using a closed loop system and continuously re-circulating the same water. That makes it possible to reuse 97% of our water.


  • I heard you don't get all of the proper nutrients through aquaponics. Will your produce be nutrient deficient? No. With Nutriunt's system design, we will optimize nutrient production. We will accomplish this by adding worms to help break down the fish solids. Worms are a remarkable asset to the ecosystem. They house special enzymes in their digestive tract that break down other valuable nutrients in the system, maximizing nutrient absorption for the plants.



About the Founder

Hello, my name is Jacolby Cross. I am from New Orleans, LA and raised in San Diego, CA. I am currently active duty Coast Guard. I have served for over 7 years as an AMT (Aviation Maintenance Technician) on the MH60J/T (Helicopter) and C130H (Four prop cargo plane), and have had the pleasure of serving in numerous places. New Jersey, North Carolina, all over Alaska, Florida, Bahamas, Haiti, Turks & Caicos, Jamaica, Puerto Rico, and Dominica Republic. When I first moved to Florida I was growing all natural produce for myself and soon after was growing for some friends and a few neighbors on my patio garden it St. Petersburg, FL. It was aggravating playing the guessing game of where our food was coming from and what was used to grow it. I was also very fond of exotic fruits and veggies. I was starting to run out of space for the pots and soil as requests grew. I knew nothing about aquaponics at the time. I had come across it in an article and read more on it. As soon as I gave it a try I was hooked and soon after, I revamped my patio garden. I was able to grow almost 4 times what I was growing with aquaponics than soil with the little bit of space that I had on my patio. As we all know, there are many entities that make things harder than they need to be. The contents of our food shouldn't be a mystery! The idea of Nutriunt was born because the demand kept growing. The neighbors and I weren't the only ones seeking good quality pure produce! That's when my love for healthy eating spliced with the need to do better ignited. I found myself yelling at the T.V. often. So I decided I wanted to do something in my own special way, to contribute to the solution against this epidemic of diseased food! So now I'm looking for outgoing healthy folks that want to see my endeavor come alive and would love to take advantage of clean  produce variety! Thank you so much for taking the time! I look forward to meeting you in the near future.
story_txt:
What is Nutriunt? 
Nutriunt will be a local organic exotic aquaponic farm that offers exotic variety. Instead of traveling miles to get to your plate, it will be possible to have it travel from farm to fork. We couldn't be more proud in that we will be providing produce and fish to our community that will be grown using the efficiency of aquaponics, free from pesticides, synthetic fertilizers, GMO’s, and growth hormones. Nutriunt will always live by the definition of what it truly means to be organic and pure. How we will accomplish this? What is going to make all of this possible is the amazing ability of aquaponics and growing in a lovely greenhouse. Aquaponics is hydroponics married with aquaculture, a sustainable ecosystem. The fish waste is converted into plant food on a biological level. In turn the plants filter the nitrates from the water to foster, while neutralizing and purifying the water for the fish. This means the crop will have an unaltered steady stream of natural organic nutrients.
Aquaponics:
Nutriunt's Goal  The Nutriunt team is trying to raise $7,000, but we are looking to shatter that with your support! Every dollar is going to be used for everything from the seed to the structure! Even if we don't meet our funding goal, we are going to make due with what we are able to raise. If we raise more than our target goal we will be able to expand the design of the growing system to offer even more organic heirloom varieties. With the current system design we will be able to produce a combination of over 1,000 heads of lettuce, leafy greens, bunches of basil, and a variety of fruits and vegetables monthly.Where your money is going?
Greenhouse
Organic seed
Tilapia 
Grow bed troughs
PVC plumbing
Fish tank
Sumps and pumps
Shale rock
Growing medium
Basic shop tools 

Your continuous support will allow Nutriunt to afford a delivery van! If you help us shatter our funding goal we will be able to deliver and make a presence at farmers markets.
What you get!What you will receive is determined by your perk selection. Your perk will include a combination of leafy greens, lettuce, and herbs. Nutriunt merchandise is included in most of the perks.Live ProduceAnother amazing feat that will be able to be accomplished is selling live produce! Aquaponics makes it possible because of the accessibility of the crop and the versatility of mother nature. The Goods  Even
before the plants begin to grow, we take care in where we attain our seed. The
seeds won't even make it to our grow beds unless they come from an organic source or a trustful association. Below are just a few of the crops that we will begin to offer upon opening:Lettuce/Leafy Greens Red RomaineOrigin: Rome
Facts: Romaine lettuce was served on the tables of Persian kings and praised for it's medicinal values.
Description: Red
Romaine Lettuce has long crunchy spoon shaped leaves that start green and fade
to profuse purple/red.
Nutrition: A
great source of vitamins A, C, high in vitamin K, dietary fiber, folate, molybdenum, fiber, manganese, potassium, biotin, vitamin b1, copper, iron, calcium, and magnesium.Use: Red Romaine is just as good as its cousin, but it will add zest and some color to a flavorful salad. Red Romaine is often used in Caesar salads for its crunch and color.Merlot LettuceOrigin: Netherlands
Facts: Merlot has one of the highest contents of antioxidants when it comes to leafy produce. Also known
as “Galactic”, this lettuce is so exquisite! Reputed to be the darkest red
lettuce in existence. 
Description: Is a striking deep dark red color and a bit of green at the base. Has
a sweet, delicate, and crispy taste. Stays sweet at all sizes.
Nutrition: Good source of Protein, Calcium, Magnesium and Phosphorus, Dietary Fiber, Vitamin A, Vitamin C, Vitamin K, Thiamin, Riboflavin, Vitamin B6, Folate, Iron, Potassium and Manganese.Use: Is great paired with any other greens. Can also be used as a beautiful garnish or enjoyed on it's own.Bronze Beauty LettuceOrigin: Chicago,
USA
Facts: Recognized
as the finest, most colorful and most delicious leaf lettuce. Also known as
Bronze Arrowhead. All-America Award winner for 1947, the year it was introduced
by Germania Seed Company.
Description: Hands down one of the best lettuces that I have had the pleasure of tasting. Is a leaf type lettuce. Sweet nutty leaves are blushed with medium bronze, mainly around the wavy leaf
margins.
Nutrition: Being
a leaf lettuce it is a good source of Protein, Calcium, Magnesium and
Phosphorus, and a very good source of Dietary Fiber, Vitamin A, Vitamin C,
Vitamin K, Thiamin, Riboflavin, Vitamin B6, Folate, Iron, Potassium and
Manganese.Use: The tender crisp leaves can be added to any mixed green salad and would be a great addition to any sandwich.Lollo Rossa LettuceOrigin: Italy
Facts: It was
discovered that Lollo Rossa has 100 times more antioxidants than common lettuce
in 1999 by scientists at the University of Glasgow.  Lollo Rossa Lettuce contains the antioxidant
quercetin, which is believed to help prevent asthma and allergies by acting as
a natural antihistamine.
Description: It
is known to be used as a supplemental lettuce to mix with other lettuces of
varying textures and flavor. It has compact rosette fan shaped leaves that are
violet in color with a pale green base.
Nutrition: Loose-leaf
lettuces such as Lollo Rossa provide vitamins A and C, folate, and iron.Use: Can be blended with other greens in a salad, garnish soups, bed for presentations, and used on sandwiches.Flashy Butter Gem LettuceOrigin: Oregon,
USA
Facts: Flashy butter gem lettuce is a romaine type lettuce. Can be harvested mini or at full maturity
with no sacrifice in flavor. Grows in a short thick bunch. Frank Morton original.
Description: This
lettuce has a soft buttery texture and dappled in crimson. 
Nutrition: Good
source for Vitamins, A, C, K, and folate, iron, and dietary fiber.Use: Gourmet quality lettuce for any salad mix.Herbs/Basil Blue SpiceOrgin: AfricaFacts: Deep fragrance with spicy vanilla overtones and a hint of lemon.Description: Has a lovely inflorescence with light purple flowers set on deep purple bracts. Nutrition: Like most other basil, blue spice is rich in Vitamin A, Vitamin C, Vitamin K, Vitamin B6, Folate, Calcium, Iron, Magnesium, Phosphorus, Potassium, Zinc, Copper and Manganese.Use: Prime for fruit salads. Can also be used in poultry dishes, marinades, dressings, and beverages. Dark Purple Opal: Origin: FranceFacts: Opal basil was first discovered in 1830 by George Bentham, a British botanist. Description: Is a sweet basil cultivar. Opal basil has egged shaped leaves that are glossy, toothed at the edge, and are dark purple in color.Nutrition: Vitamin A, Vitamin C, Vitamin K, Vitamin B6, Folate, Calcium, Iron, Magnesium, Phosphorus, Potassium, Zinc, Copper and Manganese.Use: Is commonly used in Thai, Vietnamese, and Italian foods. Opal basil can be used to make a purple pesto and the leaves can be used to make an aromatic herbed vinegar or oils.Cinnamon:Origin: Southeast AsiaFacts: Is known as Mexican spice basil. The seeds of cinnamon basil are used as a thickening agent but don't share the aromatic properties of the leaves.Description: Is smaller than sweet basil and has narrower leaves, Is know for it's darker color, cinnamon like taste, and intense aroma.Nutrition: Vitamin A, Vitamin C, Vitamin K, Vitamin B6, Folate, Calcium, Iron, Magnesium, Phosphorus, Potassium, Zinc, Copper and Manganese.Use: Goes great with fruit and is delicious in Asian, Indian, and Italian dishes. Is also a savory element to raw dishes, soups, and hot drinks.AraratOrigin: India Facts: The flowers are edible. The licoriceanise fragrance is crisp and wins taste tests among purple basil.Description: Has bi-color leaves. Purple and green mingled together. Has an unusually intense aroma and flavor. TNutrition: Vitamin A, Vitamin C, Vitamin K, Vitamin B6, Folate, Calcium, Iron, Magnesium, Phosphorus, Potassium, Zinc, Copper and Manganese.Use: Can be used in salads, on a sandwich, herbal vinegar, sauces, soups, and as a beautiful garnish.FruitKiwano - African Horned Cucumber MelonOrigin: AfricaFacts: The horned melon is one of the few melons that actually resembles a cucumber more than a melon. The kiwano is primarily cultivated in New Zealand, where it was introduced in the 1930's.Description: The kiwano has a bright deep orange skin at maturity. The flesh is a lime green color resembling Jell-O. It produces spikes across it's spattered orange and yellow skin. The melon has a sweet tart tropical banana-lime taste to it. Nutrition: The Horned Melon consists of 90% water and rich in Vitamin C. It is also a good source of iron and potassium. Use: Can be used to make a seed free juice cocktail. Is fantastic when added to smoothies. Goes great in fruit salads and sauces. The hollowed shell is perfect for a unique serving dish.Green Zebra Tomato:Origin: Washington, USAFacts: A favorite tomato of many high class chefs and restaurateurs. Description: Flesh is bright green and has a rich sweet tangy taste. Has green skin blushed with yellow-lime stripes. Nutrition: Is a great source of lycopene and has cancer fighting capacity. High in Vitamin C and Vitamin A.Use: Tastes great sliced fresh in salads. Can also be eaten like an apple right off the vine. Is also known to make a delicious green ketchup.Blue Berries Tomato:Origin: California, USAFacts: Small cherry variety from Brad Gates, Wild Boar Farms. Description: Unripe, the fruit are an amethyst purple. When mature turn a deep red where fruit was shaded and a dark purple, almost black, where it received intense sunlight.  Intense fruity flavor and very sweet. Nutrition: Very rich in anthocyanins. High in Vitamin C and A. Also a great source for potassium, iron, and lycopene.Use: Can be eaten like grapes, sliced in a fruit salad, or added whole. Can also be blended into a smoothie. Would also be great when added to sweet sauces and spreads. Yellow Pear Tomato:Origin: South AmericaFacts: Is a member of the cherry tomato family. Description: Very sweet. Resembles the shape of a pear. Nutrition: High in Vitamin C. Great source for iron and lycopene.  Use: Great for fresh eating. Great choice for tomato preserves. Adds great taste and color to any salad. Can also be a sun dried variety. Copia Tomato:Origin: California, USAFacts: They were named in honor of Copia, the American center for Food, Wine, and the Arts, in Napa California. Description: Larger tomato variety. Has golden yellow and red vertical stripes when fully ripe. The flesh is a combination of yellow and red swirled together, and is sweet and juicy.  Nutrition: As other tomatoes, the copia is a great source of lycopene. High in Vitamin A and C. Also provides iron and potassium.Use: Stunning when sliced with dark opal basil and fresh mozzarella. Can be diced and added to salads. Would also add some fire to a sandwich. Tilapia  Origin: Native to Africa ad Israel Facts: Is commercial known as the "mango fish" and can also be found in Egypt.Description: These are the locomotives of our ecosystem! The nile tilapia has distinctive vertical stripes extending as far down the body as the caudal fin with variable coloration.Nutrition: The tilapia is a lean fish. It is high in protein and iron.Use: Will also be available for purchase at maturity which takes 8-12 mos, which is about 12" weighing in at 1.5 pounds. story:
Why should I give you money?

Most of these types of campaigns are for specific projects or to help people through personal emergencies.  So why should you help a business, even if it is a small, one-person business?  

Small business in America is struggling right now, and mine is no different.  I don't ever want to challenge Smuckers in the stores, I just want to get a quality product out into the market and to share the joy that I find in the taste of fresh fruit picked at the peak of ripeness.  But until now my opportunity to do so has been limited by word of mouth.  I appreciate how much all of my friends and family have done, but Fat Lady Foods has reached the point where it needs a wider audience.  That can't happen without help.

But shouldn't a business make it on their own?  Why should people just give them money without expecting a product in return?  Quite frankly, because it is almost impossible for a small business to make it right now.  I've watched businesses open and close in the space of a few months all around where we live.  If we want to give small business a chance in this world of mega-marts and super-conglomerates, then we need to find new and original ways to help them survive.  I'm asking you to help my business survive and grow.


What are you asking, specifically?

Money is tight right now for nearly everyone.  I understand.  That's why I'm here, and that's why Fat Lady Foods needs your help.  But I am asking that you take a look at your budget and donate what you can.  $5 or $500, it doesn't matter how much.  What matters is that you care enough and believe enough in myself, my business, and what it represents to offer up some of your own funds.  That means the world to me.


What will you do with the money?

The money will go toward the following:

  • Fees and permits associated with vending at weekly farmers markets
  • Fees and permits required to be registered as a food manufacturer with The State of Texas (this would mean that FLF could sell to secondary markets such as caterers, floral shops and other gift basket providers, restaurants, bakeries and so on)
  • Equipment required for vending at weekly farmers markets including items such as a tent, tables, signage, display shelving, etc.
  • Initial deposits and continuing rental payments for use of a local certified kitchen
  • Production equipment including jars, labels, additional canning equipment, etc.


Final words

Thank you.  Whether you have contributed to this campaign, purchased jam, or helped spread the word about Fat Lady Foods, I appreciate you and what you have done.  This business wouldn't survive without you and those like you who have helped support it.  It will continue to grow as long as you and others who care about quality food keep spreading the word (and spreading jam on things, like bagels or toast!).


Thank you from the bottom of my heart.

story:
Hola. I'm R. Kelly. Yes, that is my real name...

I'm looking for some help realizing my long held dream of opening Red Line 5ive & Dime in the rapidly changing Edgewater neighborhood on Chicago's north side.                                                                                     

What is Red Line 5ive & Dime...?

I'm glad you asked.

Red Line 5ive & Dime is a contemporary urban take on the classic five and dime store with the major focus being on men's and women's new to you clothing at a single price point; $5.00. I'm not talking vintage...Think of Red Line 5ive & Dime as a clean, easy-to-shop thrift store with a Dean Martin meets Pandora soundtrack and an Urban Outfittersesque interior design sensibility...and amazing customer service. All new to you clothing will be hand picked by myself and will run the gamut from GAP to good-to-go on a Friday night and funk to functional in sizes from 0 to big is beautiful for men and women. Style and service at a price that keeps folks coming back.

In addition, Red Line 5ive & Dime will carry new clothing at a discount price and other urban essentials such as good incense, candles, mustache wax, Taschen coffee table books, battery operated Chinese good luck waving kitties, local small press cards, prints and t-shirts and other stuff that I like to be surrounded by.

Red Line 5ive & Dime will also partner with local arts oriented not for profits offering them the opportunity to display their work and generate vital income ensuring the continuation of their organizations.

The $6,500 I'm looking to raise will cover security and at least one month's rent, build out (paint, fixtures, etc.), insurance, the first two months of utilities,  a good graphic/logo designed, new and new to you product (approximately 1,000 pieces) and "hype." I'm very social and have plenty of experience at guerilla marketing so getting the word out about Red Line 5ive & Dime won't be a problem. My goal of $6,500 is realistic and obtainable and every dollar brings me closer to realizing my dream. From the bottom of my heart, thank you for considering a donation.

For every donation of $10 and over, a special gift is yours. From thank you's to t-shirts to tax free shopping....check out the perks section.

It's not called Retail Therapy for nothing...

Human beings are social animals and this need to connect drives the spirit behind Red Line 5ive & Dime. I was born to be a shopkeeper. Nothing excites me more than human behavior. Ok, maybe a great thrift store score...so why not combine the two and turn them into a viable, profitable business with an eye on social responsibility. Reduce, reuse, recycle and really care about others.

With more than 15 years retail management experience including the development and maintenance of a successful on-line store, I've got the skills, the drive and the confidence needed to make Red Line 5ive & Dime a success.

I'm one man trying to make his corner of the world a better place. To borrow from Mr. Jackson, I started with the man in the mirror. After years of battling my demons, I've been able to lay them down for almost three years. Moment by moment, smile by smile, tear by tear. At last, I understand who I am and what I want. It's now time for me to give back and affect the culture of Chicago in a positive way. I firmly believe Red Line 5ive & Dime is that vehicle.

Thank you for considering a donation to the Red Line 5ive & Dime campaign. If you can't help out financially, how about letting others know about me and my dream...? Word of mouth is priceless.

Feel free to contact me should you have any questions.

Keep making this world pretty.

R. Kelly
story_txt:
Hola. I'm R. Kelly. Yes, that is my real name...
I'm looking for some help realizing my long held dream of opening Red Line 5ive & Dime in the rapidly changing Edgewater neighborhood on Chicago's north side.                                                                                     
What is Red Line 5ive & Dime...?
I'm glad you asked. 
Red Line 5ive & Dime is a contemporary urban take on the classic five and dime store with the major focus being on men's and women's new to you clothing at a single price point; $5.00. I'm not talking vintage...Think of Red Line 5ive & Dime as a clean, easy-to-shop thrift store with a Dean Martin meets Pandora soundtrack and an Urban Outfittersesque interior design sensibility...and amazing customer service. All new to you clothing will be hand picked by myself and will run the gamut from GAP to good-to-go on a Friday night and funk to functional in sizes from 0 to big is beautiful for men and women. Style and service at a price that keeps folks coming back. 
In addition, Red Line 5ive & Dime will carry new clothing at a discount price and other urban essentials such as good incense, candles, mustache wax, Taschen coffee table books, battery operated Chinese good luck waving kitties, local small press cards, prints and t-shirts and other stuff that I like to be surrounded by.
Red Line 5ive & Dime will also partner with local arts oriented not for profits offering them the opportunity to display their work and generate vital income ensuring the continuation of their organizations.
The $6,500 I'm looking to raise will cover security and at least one month's rent, build out (paint, fixtures, etc.), insurance, the first two months of utilities,  a good graphic/logo designed, new and new to you product (approximately 1,000 pieces) and "hype." I'm very social and have plenty of experience at guerilla marketing so getting the word out about Red Line 5ive & Dime won't be a problem. My goal of $6,500 is realistic and obtainable and every dollar brings me closer to realizing my dream. From the bottom of my heart, thank you for considering a donation.
